author: {'steamid': '76561198042620952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1382, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1708443915}
review:
[h1] Genre [/h1] Ein 3D Plattformer

[h1] Story [/h1] Wir spielen einen kleinen Karton namens Newbie und sollen die B√∂sen Wild Cards aufhalten

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] Es gibt insgesamt 4 Level. Wobei das Erste als HUB World gilt. Die Level sind alle relativ Gro√ü und Semi Open World. Es gibt in jedem Level viel zum einsammeln wie z.B. Goldene B√§nder, Briefmarken & eingesperrte Karton Freunde. Einige der Briefmarken sind im Level versteckt und man muss oft Schalter bet√§tigen um an diesen heran zu kommen. F√ºr andere muss man mit Karton Freunden sprechen und deren Herausforderungen bestehen (Rennen, bestimmte Anzahl an Feinden besiegen usw.). Sterben kann man nicht, wenn man z.B. ins Wasser f√§llt spawnt man wieder am letzten Checkpoint ohne Verluste von irgendwas. Feinde lassen sich mit einer Stampfattacke besiegen, respawnen aber auch immer wieder relativ flott. Die Feinde selbst k√∂nnen uns nichts anhaben sie beschiessen uns zwar mit Feuerwerk und sto√üen uns weg aber Schaden gibt es nicht. Die Grafik ist niedlich und das Gameplay macht Spa√ü

[h1] Achievement Schwierigkeit 7/10 [/h1] Es gibt insgesamt 15 Erfolge. Hierf√ºr muss man alle Bosse und bis zu 500 Gegner besiegen, 250 mal die Auspack F√§higkeit einsetzen (extra Sprung) und alle Collectibles finden (Briefmarken, Goldene B√§nder & Karton Freunde. Die Collectibles sind sehr frustrierend zu finden denn in jedem Level muss man 200 Goldene B√§nder finden und es l√§uft immer darauf hinaus das einem 20 oder so fehlen und man keine Ahnung hat wo man noch suchen soll. Es gibt eine In Game Hilfestellung durch einen Karton Freund aber man muss immer wieder zu diesen hin gehen um dann eine kurze Szene zu sehen mit dem Standort eines der B√§nder was sehr schnell frustrierend wird

[h1] Pro/Contra [/h1]
+ Nette Grafik
+ Nettes Gameplay
+ 4 Gro√ües Semi Open World Level
+ Achievements
+ Sammelkarten
+ Deutsche √úbersetzung ist ordentlich
+ XBox 360 Controller Support

+/- Die Collectibles alle zu finden kann sehr schnell frustrierend werden wenn man denn 100% Achievements m√∂chte

[h1] Fazit [/h1] Ein wirklich Gro√üartiger gelungener 3D Plattformer mit sch√∂nem Gameplay und Gro√üen Levels. Wer Alte Klassiker aus den 90ern wie Super Mario 64, Banjo Kazooie & Co. mochte, der wird auch dieses Spiel sehr schnell ins Herz schliessen. Ein kleines Juwel im Genre, welches ich sehr Empfehlen kann

author: {'steamid': '76561197971681717', 'num_games_owned': 1250, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1751, 'last_played': 1694643068}
review:
I give the entire experience a thumb's up. If you're looking for the old school 3D collectathon vibe with varied minigames/challenges and general exploring without a whole lot of actual threat or anything at stake, this is it. It definitely has a Banjo-Kazooie vibe, despite having no ability progression. The main mechanic is that you can "unbox" for an extra jump mid-air. Each layer of box serves as a health point as well, and you can store up to 6. It makes for some interesting maneuvering sometimes, but refills are very generously distributed throughout the maps.
Speaking of, there are 3 main maps plus a hubworld to explore and I found that to be just enough content without overstaying its welcome. Took me about 20 hours to 100% those areas, though I wish the 3rd area had been a bit more of a variation. The first area is a tropical island/beach setup, then a snowy mountain, and then a jungle, which is just too similar to the first area.
Still, for $20 even not on sale it's a heck of a good time and I recommend it.

review: Great but full of bugs! This game is a lot of fun with easy controls, and each world has a set of skill-based challenges. I absolutely LOVE this game except it has an incredibly annoying bug; the screen windows and controls fail to work properly. This happens especially when jumping or unboxing, but not exclusively. It makes general actions difficult and challenges infuriating. Going back to start can usually remedy the glitch, but then I also have to back to where I was. I really hope this issue gets resolved to the game can be enjoyed the way it should be. It's too good to be undermined by this bug.

author: {'steamid': '76561199053262541', 'num_games_owned': 234, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 779, 'last_played': 1679077936}
review:
TDLR: The single player has some cool location concepts, but is unfortunately very lacking in content. Maybe for "Baby's first 3d collect-athon" it would be a good deal. Multiplayer, however, is what saves this game and makes it worth watching out for on sales. It's about as fun as 'Gang Beasts' in that regard.

THE GOOD
The tutorial island and World 2 (snowy mountains) had nice location specific gimmicks
* The story mode maps were all littered with fans of sorts, which might sound off-putting, but getting knocked into the air by air currents was an enjoyable method of travel, I'll admit.
* The multiplayer modes are all very entertaining! There is Delivery (racing), Boxing (arena battle), Thief (Coin battle), Oddbox (Fall Guys' take on Tail Tag), and Collect (Zone Control) 
* The inclusion of Bounce (the character, not the jump feature) made 100%-ing this game far less annoying in the long run, since you could essentially talk to him and deduce the location of various objects with the small camera angle he gives you, instead of wandering aimlessly for potentially hours looking for that stupid last roll of tape. (This is the only point I will give Unbox over "Goat Simulator" in terms of single player, as finding the trophies in that game with no help was almost impossible.)
* Air mobility feels nice. Using the slam button when your'e jumping over slopes feels smooth.

THE BAD
* In both modes, the player camera is not the greatest.
* The story mode is NOT multiplayer. This was to be expected, since collecting 800 gold tapes would be very convenient that way and this story mode hates convenience.
* The multiplayer mode is NOT actually supported online. You must use "remote play" to play with some friends online, which streams your audio and video to them. It's a nitpick, I know, but still.
* In both modes, the hat you are wearing effects the way your character rolls on the ground. This will effect your performance in speedruns and racing mode.
* The actual main story plummets after act 1 of the story mode, but nobody's really here for that.
* Getting off a sled in World 2 crashed my game all 3 times I've tried it. Unboxxing (double jumping) out of the sled however works fine. No idea why this happens. 
* All of the cosmetics in the game are either skins of characters from the story mode or a recolor of a Zippie (this game's take on Toad from the Mario series) which is disheartening to some, since it will mean your character will never truly look like an original work.
* Most of the cosmetic items must be earned in story mode to be used in multiplayer mode, which is extremely lame, since story mode is this game's weakness.
* The main collectible in this game is tape. TAPE??? Really?? These are DELIVERY boxes, the main collectible literally should have been MAIL, it would have made so much sense!!!

Overall, being able to do Steam Remote Play and couch co-op multiplayer on this game makes this game a total winner when it's on sale, and the game typically goes on sale for $5 or even just $3. The story mode even has a few neat ideas for hub worlds for aspiring developers today!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018390011', 'num_games_owned': 629, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1660392497}
review: Unbox: Newbie's Adventure is an incredibly fun and charming platformer game. The game features a unique concept in which players control a cardboard box and navigate through various environments, completing challenges and collecting collectibles. The game has a great sense of humor and a vibrant art style, which makes it very appealing to all ages. The controls are intuitive and the gameplay is challenging but not impossible, making it accessible to players of all skill levels. The game features a variety of levels, power-ups, and boss battles that keep it fresh and exciting. The game also includes a local multiplayer mode that adds a new level of fun and replayability. Overall, Unbox: Newbie's Adventure is a must-have game for anyone who loves platformers, it's an incredibly fun and well-designed game that will keep you entertained for hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033065307', 'num_games_owned': 2268, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1675433457}
review:
Editing my review:

I wanted to leave a quick review stating that this game does work well on the Steam Deck. It initially starts in 320x240 resolution but that can be adjusted once you reach the main menu. Once adjusted to the proper resolution (it can handle the highest), it works just great. There's a teeny bit of screen tearing around the outermost pixel of the screen's border but I think it's more a display issue than a performance issue.

Now for the edited bit - the game starts off okay, but the jumping controls quickly become more of a nuisance. Some challenges leave you unable to Unbox which means enemies get to send you way off course, timed challenges are frustrating when working against the controls, the environment, and other enemies. Overall it's just not that fun of a game - if you're looking for a platformer, you could probably do quite a bit better. Some upgrades would have been nice, to change box shapes, give additional unboxes, etc. It just has a gimmick and sticks directly to it for the entirety of the game. The only boss (box?) fight that I bothered to do was just unreliable, and it felt like coincidence that I happened to win.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043135631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2248, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1664339421}
review:
This game flew under the radars of many folks.
It's been on steam since 2016, It's a long time.
And yet, only a few people know, that it exists.
Which is a shame, because It is a lovely game.
Very much a hidden gem, under-rated at best.
In this game you will play, as a cardboard box.
Your goal is to simply help out the other ones.
There are various collectibles. Like duct tapes.
And it has some vibes of retro 3D platformers.
Yknow, like Mario64, Conker, Spyro, Croc, etc.
But: It is a much more fast-paced platforming.
There were some precision requiring sections.
And also a lot of jumps requiring fast thinking.
Very cute visuals, also very lovely open world.
A ton of stuff to do, some decent mini-games.
There are some nice, racing ones for example.
Overall: Just a ton of fun, really recommend it.
Especially if you like 3D platformers and such.
I think this game deserves a lot more praising.
Because this is just a neat modern platformer.
It definitely earned a positive review from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117320859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1660189231}
review:
Un juego interesante, con una jugabilidad medio b√°sica, pero que no deja de ser entretenido.
En si manejamos cajitas... que por su formato cuadrado, el manejarlas puede en algunas ocasiones no ser tan f√°cil como puede parecer. Juego recomendado!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024153634', 'num_games_owned': 544, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 728, 'last_played': 1656615146}
review:
I'm so sad this never got a sequel

Out of all the indie 3D platformers chasing the feelings of the ones from yesterday, Unbox does something the rest fail to do. It doesn't have a fancy roster of attacks - it's mostly a two button game (though not without depth). It doesn't try for faithful 1:1 re-imagining. No 3D Mario complex movement and succumbing to the Nintendo game design mold. No Rare-esque collectathon obsession. It's not trying to be a Banjo 3 or a Super Mario 128. No Yooka-Laylee here.

What Unbox does is manage to capture the *spirit* of those classics. I'd probably consider Hat in Time to be the closest thing to a new, great, spirited 3D platformer. Is Unbox as big or as polished? No. But it *feels* like an N64/GCN classic. More than anything else in its field

-- I couldn't find anywhere else in the review to put this but I feel like it might be of note to say that Unbox reminds me most of Ty the Tasmanian Tiger --

I think it's because it takes it's whole box theme and throws all its weight behind it. There's something incredible charming about moving like a box. You don't play as a box with feet, no. You play and move as a literal box - physics and all. I suppose there's something almost Monkey Ball to the experience in how you have to focus intensely on your movement lest you bounce off in an unwanted direction. And the mechanic of unboxing, what is essentially 6 double jumps you can use strategically, is clever as all hell. It makes me think Unbox successfully overcomes the comparison syndrome ie "this game is like X" or "Unbox is Y + Z". Unbox feels truly unique and isn't concerned with copycatting its comparisons. It feels like the devs were able to really identify the elements of a 3D platformer and use them as their own without having to drag along the identities of where they came from

It's not perfect. The biggest, most horrific oversight is this objective arrow/compass that takes up far too much of the UI. It's minimized form is visible at all times and it steals what feels like half the screen anytime it appears. Ant it appears anytime you talk to someone. It's honestly baffling that it was kept this way and without any option to disable it. I bound the button that activates it (D-Pad Down iirc) to one of the stick clicks this way I could immediately close it anytime it opens. After that the game became much more tolerable. But you better hope your eyes can mask away the ugly banner.

Having dialogue be consequential as a result really highlights how shallow NPC dialogue is. The named cast are above average but any world inhabitant is bound to say absolutely nothing. The one pseudo-attack you have (you won't be attacking much though) is a slam you preform mid-air. It's bound to B. And it reveals just how...weird the controls are. Jumping and unboxing are mapped to RT/RB and LT/LB respectively. Y is alternating camera views, X is respawn, A is interact (and to skip cutscenes, which is unfortunate because the dialogue boxes are so slow I'd accidentally skip cutscenes anytime my brain auto-ed the A button). It's like someone really, really liked those Dark Souls controls and were deadset on putting them into their platformer. It doesn't not work, but it feels weird. I couldn't find any comfortable way to remap them so I just got use to them. 

Matt Griffin who would later show his insane talent on The Impossible Lair does a lot of the music here and it's fantastic. Sound design all around is great. The artstyle is endearing and it gets points for having a plot that's actually engaging. The movement is weird and I love it. It's such it's own beast that it feels like you're constantly relearning how to play (in the best way possible). The verticality allowed is what I'll remember most from the game. I think it was paced well and, aside from some atrocious load times (you only need to sit through a loading screen once per world but it can take up to a minute) it feels like the game respects your time. Especially when you can talk to Bounce to get hints as to where the last collectables might be. I'm considering picking the game up as a speedrun but trying to maximize movement efficency feels like it'd be a nightmare (Speedrun only has four 4+ year old runs recorded). I usually loathe number scores but in spite of the giant yellow '68' metascore on the store page, I'd say Unbox deserves another 10 points at the very least

It's charming as hell, distinctly unique, enjoyable and a breeze to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986413856', 'num_games_owned': 2330, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1650604579}
review:
This is a short and simple, yet charming, 3D Platformer Collectathon reminiscent of Banjo & Kazooie.

The main feature is the physics based movement, similar to Monkey Ball, the one difference being that you roll around a cube instead of a ball. This can cause some frustrations during some more precise jumps, but there is no punishment for failing aside returning to one of the many checkpoints around the map.
You have 6 "Unbox" points that serve both as you health meter and the number of extra jumps you can do, refilling the points either by reaching a checkpoint or getting one of the many respawning health pickups around the map.

There are 3 worlds alongside the hub, doing the bare minimum to finish the story might take only a few hours. I took about 10 to finish everything 100% (only missing one of the mystery vials on the last world).
The skill required is low to medium, so this game is on a good spot for young kids.

Each world requires a number of stamps (this game's stars/jiggies) to finish. They show around the map as collectables and as rewards for missions, which can be stuff like races, combat arenas or time trials.
The rest of the collectables (trapped boxes, tape and mystery vials) only unlocks new cosmetics. A NPC can help you find missing collectables, but he only shows the general location of it and only does it one item at a time. Hes also the only NPC you can't track with the GPS system and have to find manually.

There is not much else to say about it. A short little hidden gem, its not A Hat In Time, but its fun and doesn't overstays it's welcome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070686374', 'num_games_owned': 1753, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1654317266}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997940096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1649030689}
review: I mean... I'll be honest, it works. It's playable, but... it gets old really quick. I do like that you can kinda zoom accross the level with some well times unboxeseses, but I'd rather the game actually challenge you to platform proper. The moves are jump, move, butt slam and unbox, which is a mid-air jump in the cost of one health... that's it. :U The levels are open world things that involve collecting this and popping a switch that. Doesn't help that the physics feel like you're constantly on ice. The characters are bland, the story is bland, the music is... okay, It's all just... bland. I feel kinda bad saying that, but there are far better 3D platformers out there to spend my time on. Even if it were cheaper at half price, I can't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972584572', 'num_games_owned': 1637, 'num_reviews': 386, 'playtime_forever': 641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1626926812}
review:
Beaten - 10 Hours

A n64 collectathon platformer throwback game that, unlike Hat in Time or something, takes place in several larger open worlds (not huge, mind you) instead of focused themed levels.  Emphasis in these is completing challenges in each level (or enough of them) to take on the boss.  There are a lot of extra things to do/collect that you dont HAVE to and largely serve no major purpose other than unlocking new swag for your customizable look. 

A fun game that I wouldnt hold up in an S Tier collectathon list, but is certainly maybe a B tier one.  A fun game, especially for kids. Nothing too challenging in it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035100973', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 766, 'playtime_forever': 575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1613863051}
review:
Disclaimer: My scores/reviews are almost always based on having bought the game at close to the "lowest historical price" on steam at time of purchase.

Quick score: 4/5

Notes: The movement is a bit goofy and simple. But the exploration, world, characters, and "collectathon" gameplay is enjoyable.

9 hours to 100% the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198363222243', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1057, 'last_played': 1614197660}
review: Fantastic callback to the golden age of 3D platformers. In a lot of ways this was the game I wanted Super Mario  Odyssey to be. It's very well paced with enough variety in the story to feel like you got your money's worth, but it also offers a huge set of collectables for those that want more after the credits roll. Fantastic experience all around, with good decent graphics, funny aesthetic, and some really dark secrets hidden in there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105647532', 'num_games_owned': 459, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 861, 'last_played': 1611015387}
review: Fun and relaxing adventure game with quirky mechanics

author: {'steamid': '76561198046443897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1610691437}
review:
A very chill retro-inspired collectathon. Don't expect any precision platforming or particularly difficult puzzles. The mechanics are simple, challenge times are generous, and checkpoints are plentiful. It's totally kid/family friendly.

Exploring the different levels and stumbling upon all their nooks and crannies was a joy. The unboxing mechanic adds a lot of potential for verticality and freedom of movement, and I feel like the level design incorporated it quite seamlessly. It just [i]feels[/i] good to sail through the air from point to point or rocket up into the sky. The (many, many) characters are charming and memorable and, just like the magical old Rare platformers I grew up on, the little side stories and secrets you catch glimpses of make the world feel more vibrant and mysterious than some big AAA open world titles.

I did encounter the CTD sledding bug, and load times seemed a little long. Challenges got a bit repetitive, as well. Overall, though, Unbox was a great game. 100%ing it in about 12 hours felt like just the right playtime to explore everything it had to offer without it getting stale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064824558', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1585884979}
review: From recent memory, I can't remember playing a 3D platformer as janky as this. Gameplay basically revolves around doing a series of pointless minigames or collecting hundreds of useless little collectibles. I know that this is a collectathon-type game, but it absolutely does not feel satisfying at all here. What's funny is that there is a dedicated "reset" feature, as if the devs knew the physics in the game were so bad that it is guaranteed you will constantly end up getting yourself stuck. Considering that there are other great 3D platformers on Steam like A Hat in Time, Spyro, Battle for Bikini Bottom, or even freaking Psychonauts from 2005, there is seriously no reason to play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301746397', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1606522500}
review:
When I started the game, it really surprised me how the box physics seemed to work, while I didn't like the clunky box mechanics as they interfered with platforming a bit, it was more than made up for with the up to 6 extra jumps. The jumps, though attached to the lives (which are only lost when touching fire or being blown up by explosives) are often easily replenished and often did not feel like a crutch for the game. 

It's a nice short platformer collectathon, 7/10. Would unbox and play again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198440786344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1633349521}

author: {'steamid': '76561197961230622', 'num_games_owned': 1720, 'num_reviews': 150, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1604288122}
review:
I really wanted this to be better, but I have to go with no. There are just better 3D platformers out there even on PC right now. I don't have a problem with the mapping of the controls, but the jank of them and how difficult it is to ACTUALLY control your character make what should be simple tasks often frustrating or seemingly impossible. This is a combination of the control feeling bad, and bad level design. E.g. needing to roll a ball, uphill, into a curbed switch, with no way to actually like, do that but keep bumping into it and hoping the physics work in your favor. Or the "race" you do in a car (instead of with your character) where the car just randomly inverts onto its' rear bumper on flat ground and the "flip car" button doesn't actually do anything because the ground detection is so faulty.

I honestly think poor level design is like 90% of the games' problem, for me. You have to collect stamps to get through a level, but the hidden stamps have almost no tell range (the tutorial character will show you clips of where they are, but the sections are so samey it doesn't often help), and the challenges given by the NPCs often are designed to just limit or remove your control - I think over half of them either remove your extra jump ability, or stick you in a car, or literally strap something to you that completely breaks the ground detection for your character where I was getting constantly stuck on flat ground, unable to move or do a normal jump. If the challenges were just you doing something in your normal box mode, even with the completely random timers (some I ended first try with 75% of the time left, others I had 2-3 seconds left even though I didn't mess up as bad, it's all over the place) it'd at least be less annoying.

If everything worked well, the game would probably be very easy, but I'm in the last level and it's just gotten more and more frustrating to play - not because of actual challenge, but because of pure jankiness. Initial impression of the game was that it was a cute and somewhat novel take on the genre but it just fails to do anything special and instead suffers from too many weird decisions and poor design. All the worlds could be half their size without cutting anything notable, and there's no fast travel at all. Each stage seems to have a huge area of just "dead space" in it that makes traversal take longer for no particular reason. 

If you have played every other 3D platformer out there, and desperately need more, and can get this on super cheap sale, the first world is at least OK. But that's about as much as I can recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025087928', 'num_games_owned': 1005, 'num_reviews': 446, 'playtime_forever': 734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 734, 'last_played': 1602499027}
review:
Chill platformer collect-a-thon style game. There's enough content across the couple of worlds (3 main islands) to keep you entertained for a fair few hours. The game excels when you're just left to your own devices to go explore at your own pace and complete whatever quests (or random finds) you come across. The unboxing main skill works really well and the controls are very good (on gamepad at least) for being able to launch yourself wherever you want to go. Seeing something interesting in the distance on the map and being able to move quickly through the air to go check it out never got old.

Puzzles and combat are in there but extremely simple. A few additional ideas in there are ok like driving vehicles but nothing complex or deep. Geared toward the younger crowd for the story etc. 

However as a game you can throw on some of your own music and just unwind your brain as you explore, it's worthwhile. Not AAA grade, but it's well put together and I didn't experience any crashes etc. Pretty fine for an indie and worth grabbing on sale if you're after something that would slot right on in to the N64 era of platformers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073359472', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1023, 'last_played': 1601414127}
review:
Juego de plataformas tipo Super Mario 64, debes recolectar todos los sellos que hay esparcidos en los diferentes niveles, los mapas son bastantes grandes y muy verticales gracias al original movimiento del protagonista de este juego.

Es un juego que al principio parece un poco raro y se controla muy diferente de lo que uno esta acostumbrado, pero cuando se le pilla el truco a ser una caja se hace muy divertido de controlar.

El juego es muy redondo (o cuadrado) tiene varios coleccionables diferentes y varios retos que nos iran propiniendo en los diferentes niveles para poder conseguir los sellos. El juego tiene mucha exploracion de niveles y se hace un gustazo explorar los niveles ya que estan plagados de dialogos chorras y recobecos secretos por todas partes aparte de otros secretos bastante ocultos y muy gratificantes de encontrar.

Lo recomiendo al 100% solo hay que darle una oportunidad hasta hacerse con el incontrolable control de ser una caja.

author: {'steamid': '76561198261204358', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 956, 'last_played': 1703335324}
review: Very fun game not a game you want to play all day long but a nice one to take a break from your main games recommended

author: {'steamid': '76561198025510154', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1558550876}
review:
3D platforming RPG. You are a box. You are a prototype self-delivering package, exploring the land of package delivery, interacting with other packages, doing quests, completing challenges, and dealing with Wild Cards, which are renegade packages that won't be delivered.

You move by tumbling. Tumbling a rectangular solid at speed over uneven terrain is not an exact science. Motion sickness advisory. Otherwise, generally fun and funny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198164820202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1595717442}
review:
honestly, if you want a decent platformer experience this is fine. however if you're looking for something extraordinary, this wouldn't be a good pick for a few reasons:

#1: lack of difficulty and content. i am good at platformers, and this was a walk in the park. consequently it took me 6 hours to beat. not only that but there's no replay value. once you've done a mission there's no reason to go back and do it again. 

#2 bad controls. the controls for this game are sub par. you get extra jumps and to activate them you use left click, despite the spacebar being the default jump button. the F key is used for firing rockets and advancing text SOMETIMES. other times its space. this game cant make its mind up with its controls.

#3 jank. the world this game takes place in has many instances of jank and feels pretty unpolished. a low poly version of things will render when you're right next to them. things too far away from the camera are blurred, but the blur effect looks awful. not only that but sometimes levels and missions will have certain elements blurred out when they're in front of the sky when the other half looks regular. level geometry can sometimes trap your box and you have to respawn.

#4 annoying quirks. characters in missions will talk to you all the time while you're doing them and its always annoying. sometimes its helpful but this is rare. cutscenes and box animations are very sub par, with boxes just having a still image as their faces. there are way too many collectibles compared to the required content of the game.

#5 combat in this game feels out of place and unrefined. if you want fun exciting combat go elsewhere because there is auto aim, and the key for firing sucks, and the missles you shoot are homing and the enemies are a cakewalk to avoid, and the bosses are very very very easy as you can respawn infinitely and not loose progress, just long and tedious. yes that was a run-on sentence, there was a lot to run-on about

#5: positives. this game's actual platforming feels unique and is a fresh new experience. it felt very fluid and very satisfying when it worked well. sometimes your box will "slide" around too much and make some tight jumps a near impossibility but this is rare and avoidable with better skill. every new area was huge, had lots to explore and was fun. the race missions and primarially platforming missions were by far the best part of the game, and was super fun

author: {'steamid': '76561198122258825', 'num_games_owned': 3711, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1586741289}
review:
[list][*][b][h1]Morlan's shorts:[/h1][/b][/list]
It's a silly, colourful, not-much-brain-required-y kind of game! The whole atmosphere is quite enticing but keep in mind..it [b]is[/b] silly. This isn't Tomb Raider open world! It's just pure silly (third time you said that -Ed) fun, to relax (but work for it as well.. it has some challenging moments) and immerse yourself in a cartoony postal-office world where collecting counts. In fact the main aim of the game [b]is[/b] collecting to perfection so make sure you like finding and collecting items. Bit on the up-side of pricing so maybe wait..
[b]Don't waste more time reading lengthy reviews.. time is of the essence![/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198035655574', 'num_games_owned': 1323, 'num_reviews': 204, 'playtime_forever': 984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 984, 'last_played': 1590873752}
review:
Had the ol‚Äô lockdown blues past few days so I was really in the mood for an old 3D platformer type game to keep me busy but not take up too much concentration. Unbox: Newbie‚Äôs Adventure is a cute casual 3D platformer which I think fit the bill pretty well.

Although it has most of the classic characteristics of an old 90s 3D platformer; bright colourful graphics, hub world, collectables, slightly cheesy story, antagonist and characters, what Unbox does slightly differently is the movement mechanic.
If you haven‚Äôt noticed already, you are in fact, a box. You roll around as said box and you only really have one way of navigating the space or doing anything, which is jumping. No crouching, backflipping, wall jumping or any of that stuff you might possibly find in a usual 3D platformer here. Newbie just jumps to his heart‚Äôs content. You can do a usual jump, but you are also given the ability to double, triple, quadruple jump, ect, upwards of 6 times after your initial jump. You do this by collecting pickups (which actually double as your health). This makes it so you have to make sure you are managing your jumps and stocking up on pickups, it also makes for a quite fun and easy way to get around the maps. It‚Äôs a very basic movement mechanic but it makes it all the more casual really and it was something I appreciated whilst playing this in the mood I was in.
In total there are 3 main levels and a hub area for you to explore, this doesn‚Äôt sound a lot and it isn‚Äôt really but the maps are pretty huge and there are a fair few collectables in each area. This includes 200 ‚Äúgolden packing tapes‚Äù per area, which is a lot! I did have my worries with this at first as I do enjoy collectables in these games but know how frustrating it can be when you have a big map and you have to search every nook and cranny for one collectable you‚Äôve missed. Thankfully the game has enough hints to actually make it very manageable. If you get really stuck, there is a character you can ask who will show you a small preview of where a collectable is. From the preview you can then try and figure out what is in its surroundings to determine where it may be.

 If you played this game and only got the required amount of collectables to move on this would be a pretty short game, but if you, like me, actually for some reason enjoy the collectable collecting in 3D platformers it will take you a significant amount more time to complete.
The game felt really short to me, I blasted through this game in two days in two sittings so I thought it was a really short game but apparently it took me 16.4 hours according to Steam so that isn‚Äôt actually really that short, I just no-lifed the game a little too hard. I was a little sad when I completed it to be honest because I was enjoying how casual this game is.

In terms of difficultly it‚Äôs really easy, there are challenges in the game but they aren‚Äôt really any challenge, usually in these kinds of games there is at least one part of it I get frustrated with and it takes me a few tries (Stupid boss fights (looking at you Yooka-Laylee‚Ä¶) or higher difficulty timed challenges or races) but there was none of that in Unbox. I could completely understand that maybe some people may see this as too easy, but I guess it just depends on what you are looking for. If you want a casual/easy game it‚Äôs great for that, but if you wanted something engaging that gives you a challenge I can see how it may fall short.

All in all it‚Äôs a fun addition to the, what feels like quite a small collection of, old style 3D platformers here on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999083667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 819, 'last_played': 1590895679}

author: {'steamid': '76561198063042468', 'num_games_owned': 294, 'num_reviews': 188, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1589447613}
review:
Even though you'd initially not correlate this game with Wuppo, I mention it for 2 reasons:
1) The attention for detail is extraordinary in both games;
2) For a 2D game I was surprisingly immersed into the Wuppo world due to the OST, character development, (humorous) story and atmospheric worlds, so I was motivated and felt to make progress vs. I didn't feel engaged with the 3D world and its  characters in Unbox; e.g. a forgettable, mellow OST that works counter-productive, I couldn't care less about any of the shallow chars and their unintelligble and sometimes annoying voices, and the story is lackluster. It's nice to be on sunny islands or icy mountains, but if there's nothing that keeps you moving but being a bit creative here and there ‚Äî and you don't really feel you're making progress either ‚Äî then why bother with further emptiness?!

Unlike others, I had no problems with the controls though, and you're basically very OP with a sextuple jump ability = discouraging the players to challenge themselves ...

5/10 ‚Äî It seems so obvious this game was made for friends & family; especially the young ones. Barely any satisfaction for me!

author: {'steamid': '76561198122665127', 'num_games_owned': 1078, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1589410348}
review: It's such an underrated gem; I don't even know why people just don't know about this game. I was searching for a fun platform game, similar to Croc 2 which I loved dearly when I was a kid. And I found this. It's rather a collectathon like Banjo-Kazooie, but I still had a blast with it. The whole world is well-built, the story is simple but cute (perfect even for little kids), and the characters, jokes, references are delightful. I 100% completed the game in 15 hours (first playthrough with no guides) and I completed the last 1/3 of the game on stream with my viewers who also loved the game. It's a really chill game with tons of exploration, secrets and fun gameplay. I only had small problems during the whole game, such as there are no maps and occasionally the clues for missing stuff aren‚Äôt that clear, the music could get a bit boring after a while (more songs would have helped on this issue), but my biggest problem is that it's a bit short, because it was such a fun experience, I wanted to have more. Maybe in a sequel we can have more? I hope so, it deserves one. I guarantee you‚Äôll have fun with this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198090245601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1614555252}
review: Unbox: Newbie's Adventure is a good game. I find the casual and bright colored feel very relaxing. The music is also relaxing. Being a box is unique and I like that you can dress up your box. You can also unlock different clothing from the challenges. Some of the challenges *are* challenging and it's nice. The controls seem weird at first but you get used to it. It's very smooth. If you like collecting things and a being a completionist, this game is for you. I do recommend this game and it's very fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198266073876', 'num_games_owned': 571, 'num_reviews': 351, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1587684969}
review:
-:Updated 13th September to reflect 100%ing it:-

From the moment you start this game you can tell where it gets its inspiration and thats the games of Rare in the 90s. From the cute nonsense babbling characters to the light sense of humour, this is a love letter (no pun intended) to the likes of Banjo and so far I love it. The first world is brimming with charm; from the boxes that follow you around and welcome you to the little cars you can drive. I always think that you can tell the quality of a 3D platformer by how much you want to just forget about the point of it and explore, and this one had me doing it from the start (which is frustrating that it starts with a locked in tutorial).


Amount of content -

1x Hub World
3x Quest Worlds

Each world will take you around 2hrs minimum. I think most people will play it for between 8-10hrs and it took me 16hrs to 100% it. There is enough content to warrent the asking price, especially when you consider that the quest worlds are considerably bigger than a level in a game like Banjo.

Gameplay -

On the surface this is a collectathon like Mario64, Banjo etc, but it is not just copying them and I love the fact that it is also trying to bring something new to the table, which comes in the form of the unbox mechanic. This allows you to jump up to 6 times without landing, enabling crazy big jumps. The game suggests your health is connected to the unbox mechanic, however there are very few things that actually make you lose health which for me does diminish the excitement of it by the end.

Another way in which it builds on the platformers it takes inspiration from is the amount of character interactions. Not only are their quests to find, but people to talk to about the world you are exploring adding further flavour to the world you are tumbling through.

The difficulty of the game is similar to the likes of Banjo with a mixture of stupidly easy to more fiddly tasks. However the tone of the game gives you the feeling of relaxed fun even when trying to judge the gap between two distant boats you want to jump to.

Finally there is the customisation of your plain brown box. Completing the tasks and parts of the story lead to customisation unlocks which means you can turn your boring packaging into a weird bounding wonder. So if definining the protagonist your way is important to you then it is there and it is easy to do (you just need to find the tailor, which took me about 10mins after the first island unlocks).

Graphics and Technical Stuff.

The graphics are a mixed bunch with a combination of some great water textures and rock textures combined with some very plain ones mixed in, which works for the most part but at times can seem a little strange (watch the video above and you will see what i mean). However I found its short comings did not hinder the gameplay, which based on the first world I love.

It has an uncapped framerate and on my 970 rig will all settings maxed I was getting around 100fps at 1080p and there were no noticable major dips or stuttering. You can adjust things like FOV if you want and I know this is an important issue for some.

I would like to note that the game did crash for me while I was messing with the settings, but I suspect this was my firewall, because when I logged back in I had to allow the game access to areas my firewall didn't auto allow. After this initial crash I had no other bugs or crashes playing the game, however there was a little screen tearing which was largely removed by uncapping the framerate (others have suggested turning on vsync in your GPU control panel).

Controls -

How the character controls is important in a platformer as much as any other and I found the controls to be good; although controlling an object with sharp corners meant I needed a few moments to get to grips with how the box handles (because it does handle like a box and not like a ball). The vehicle controls do feel a bit looser and I am not sure how much that is me or the game.

The developers recommend a controller and because it is a 3D platformer I would agree, however I found it perfectly playable with WASAD and a mouse (mouse controls the camera and unbox mechanic while keyboard is used to move jump and interact). I could not get my DS4 to work with it natively, if that is how you like to game. However it worked great with my Xbox Elite and its paddles.

One issue I forgot to mention when I reviewed this initially was the fact that the controls are not customisable. So if that is a major issue for you, then you will need to take that into consideration.

Multiplayer -

This is local only and while it looks fun from YouTube videos I never had a chance to play it.

For Parents -

There is nothing in this game that would not be suitable for children of any age. The fact that enemies do not damage you, (only push you flying into the air and into the water grrr) and the fact that all enemies are boxes make it very kid friendly. Humour and tone has some more mature ideas but there is nothing sexual or particularly violent underpinning this game.

Overall-

All in all, I think this is a great game and I love my time within it. It is the 3D platformer I have been waiting for and wet my appetite for Yooka next year.

Hope this review helps anyone trying to decide whether to buy it. My advice is watch the video above on the shop page, it really does give a very good idea of what you are buying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049118964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1580161227}
review:
Unbox: Newbie's Adventure is a fantastic 3D Platformer created by developer Prospect Games. And when I call it fantastic, I mean I think it's fantastic, even if it's not a great game. That's to say, I think I'll end up loving it more than most people. 

It's a cute game with a lot of charm, a great central mechanic, and it does a lot of things really well. But there's not much in the way of structure, and the missions aren't very good. Still, this might be the best indie 3D platformer out there today!

For more, check out my video review:
https://youtu.be/VQ_nIoRo9vA

author: {'steamid': '76561198103074356', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1569797709}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041165175', 'num_games_owned': 1769, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1569173799}
review:
Unbox is a platformer where you play as a self-delivering box who works for the global postal service. There are three open-world areas you explore. Within these areas, you have to collect a number of stamps either by completing challenges or by finding them in hidden locations before taking on the boss. While the open areas are kind of neat to explore, the missions are boringly basic. 

Each mission varies but they are usually the most standard challenges you can think of such as collecting 20 items, time challenges, climbing up to the top of the mountain, and other standard mission objectives. While there really isn‚Äôt anything wrong with the missions in themselves they just are not interesting. Usually, in the platforming genre, I can overlook simple mission design if the core gameplay of running and jumping is enjoyable but Unbox does not have engaging core-gameplay. Moving around the cube just doesn‚Äôt feel slick or enjoyable, just clunky. Plus, the hexa-jump ability that is tied together with the health system makes it impossible to die from enemies. Rather enemy boxes just push you around or make you float in place for several seconds, so I found that to be annoying as well. Lastly, while the plot initially seems charming it quickly becomes stale with very plain dialogue and a pretty bland plot for the majority of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018457264', 'num_games_owned': 1319, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1566872433}
review:
While the game has a LOT of charm, I simply cannot recommend this game after playing through the initial tutorial and starting the first island for one reason alone: CONTROLS.

The game seems to be a platformer, but the controls and character movement of Newbie (your character) are... frustrating, to say the least. I spent almost five minutes trying to jump up one area to get a collectible, with the following issues: 1. Since your character is a box, and you "roll" around (even in the air??), precise jumping is near impossible. 2. Rolling around is either too fast, or too slow, even when changing the sensitivity of the analog stick. 3. The box physics is almost *too* good, because as you'd expect, square edges don't make for smooth rolling (thus, #1). 4. Jumping is almost never high enough to get you where you need to be, except when you overshoot it and then you jump way too high/far. This includes the "unbox" jump, which is incredibly high yet also hard to judge just how high.

On the initial "platforming" segment on the island, if this was almost any other 3D platformer I have ever played, I could have made the jumps easily within a minute or so, and MAYBE even fallen once or twice in the process. But no! Not here! It literally took me nearly 15 minutes just to go through the tedious and frustrating process of jumping a total of maybe 6 times to get to the different platforms. Mind you, I'm not the best platformer guy out there and I tend to fall to my death more often than I would like or should, however the controls/movement in this game simply make it absolutely unplayable for me.

I really wanted to like and play through this one. Sadly, I cannot, and can't recommend others do so either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198290452849', 'num_games_owned': 415, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1565522834}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051881127', 'num_games_owned': 1349, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 936, 'last_played': 1564990287}
review:
Delightful first area, full of various platforming activities/challenges housed in smaller levels accessed through a larger interactive hub area. I had fun learning and becoming skilled at the box-jumping mechanics, and went off the beaten path searching for collectables and challenging myself with time trials.

Unfortunately, in the second hub area, I quickly and repeatedly encountered a game-breaking bug - where toboggan sled rides can too-easily end in a game crash/exit. This prohibits further progress and full enjoyment of the game, and it's a shame, because the sled rides in a snowy area (contrasted with the tropical first level) were otherwise really fun. It seemed the sled physics, paired with jumping out of the sled, just couldn't be handled by the in-game engine (it's not my rig - and the bug carried over across a couple of my computers, game uninstall/reinstalls, etc).

Maybe there's potentially lots of great material in the game that I haven't played... but for the time being (and for more than a year prior to writing this review - still not fixed as of this writing despite having applied all updates and checked back in), I haven't been able to access it, and it hasn't been patched despite this persisting a long time, so I may never know. I also hesitate to invest further time into the game because of concern I might encounter other such issues. For these technical reasons, I can't recommend the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995815016', 'num_games_owned': 2020, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1560723480}
review:
Unbox is a 3D platformer similar to games from the 90s, featuring sentient self delivering cardboard boxes as the worlds inhabitants, collectibles, and a hub/level system. As far as the gameplay goes, it's some solid fun, but there's a lot to unpack here.

It's a reasonably short game, each level requires stamps to take on the boss and access the next level, each level requiring more stamps than the previous. Majority of them you earn through some seriously fun minigames (fun boss fights too!), unfortunately you may find yourself drudging through the nicely designed thematic levels to find the remaining hidden stamps which can be a bit of a box-ache to find - which is part of the game I suppose, however on the last level it felt a bit excessive.

The quirky world, story and inhabitants are enjoyable, and the janky movement is good fun when you get the hang of it. As a game about exploring nooks and crannies the levels are really well thought out and creative.

Although I didn't manage to find all the hidden logs and gold tape scattered across the levels, I don't feel an urge to continue playing to hunt them down unfortunately, so replayability is based on whether you want to do that.

Your box character can be customised, with new boxes and accessories unlocked through the activities or collecting all the tape on a level. Personal favourite box was the Shark, with a moustache accessory, classy af.

---

I definitely recommend Unbox, especially if you're looking for a casual time waster / brain switch off game, or something child friendly!
Side note: It's also available on Switch, which might be preferable.

If the developers are planning a sequel, go for it. I'd love a sequel, expand on what you do in each level - more minigames, things to do, collectibles, levels, expand on the multiplayer -  player made tracks?, there's definitely mod potential here.

Die Story ist nicht weltbewegend, sie l√§uft einfach gut mit und passt. Das Ziel ist Briefmarken zu sammeln. Sie erh√§lt man indem man Aufgaben erf√ºllt wie Rennen fahren, was einzusammeln uvm. Aber einige sind auch auf der Spielwelt verteilt. Hat man genug gesammelt gibt es einen Boss Kampf. Das ganze muss in mehreren Welten gemacht werden. Jede ist sehr sch√∂n aufgebaut. Leute mit einem Sammeltrieb kommen hier auf ihre Kosten. Viel einzusammeln und zu suchen. Mit einem Controller l√§sst sich das Game gut harmonisch spielen. Man kann seinen Spielcharakter auch optisch anpassen, um seine eigene Box zu kreieren. Die Spielzeit ist nicht die l√§ngste, aber f√ºr die Art des Spiel vollkommen ok. author: {'steamid': '76561198051443870', 'num_games_owned': 395, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 355, 'last_played': 1563677007}
review:
Being an avid fan of adventure / platform games in the style of Banjo-Kazooie and A Hat in Time, I had to pick this up because my desire to play with boxes took control. While there isn't exactly much weight to this game, it has enough going for it that I would suggest picking it up for your child or if you don't feel like being too stressed.

The game is somewhat of a pushover, but that could be just my experience from playing thousands of hours of these type of titles, but there's nothing too difficult about this apart from maybe some of the challenges and awkward controls and combat. There is almost no punishment to dying or failing, levels are pretty straightforward, if not far too spread out.

My main frustration came in trying to jump around and finding myself constantly overshooting platforms as well as managing to get shoved in some random specific geometry. Enemies will ruin your day and seem a bit too hard for an otherwise easy trek of collecting.

While the game tries to be helpful, it goes pretty overboard with telling you that something is nearby, shoving hints, health, and checkpoints almost every ten feet, and repeats past advice.

Overall, this is simple fun. You're not going to find some King of Platformers here or even a competitor to Banjo-Kazooie or Super Mario 64, I would actually put this game next to Goat Simulator minus the glitches. As for the price tag, I can't bring myself to say it's worth $20 so I suggest you get it on sale for at least half off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136545980', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1554241585}
review: longer play sessions of this game give me nausea that's why I don't recommend it, there is some fun in the game though - big world to explore, funny dialogues, graphics are good except awful detail popping. the button mapping is a bit weird and you can't customize it, you can only select one of few presets but the button prompts don't change so it's better to use the default  preset. additionally the game always crashed when I tried to jump off the sled after falling on the side. the "combat" sucks though, enemies are more of an annoyance than challenge and you can't die anyway, you only take damage from enemies armed with fireworks but even then you just respawn in last touched checkpoint, the only challenge were the race missions. overall a fine game but the fact it almost made me vomit is a bit too much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076052686', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1535563787}
review:
I'm gonna be honest: I was looking forward to playing this game. And the first hour or two prove that this game has amazing potential. Unfortunately it was all squandered.

Let's start with the posititves: the overall feel of the game is cute, innocent and lighthearted to 11. Playing the first stage felt liberating and the mechanics seemed perfect. There's a lot of places to visit, micro challenges to tackle and collectibles to get. Climbing the radio tower is probably the best the game has to offer. But as I played more stages and delved deeper into the mechanics, I realized the fatal flaw of the game, the thing that totally breaks it for me. [b]YOU'RE A BOX[/b]

Hear me out: it could be original, funny and a nice way to make this game stand out from other collectathons, but we need to look at the controls and gameplay itself to understand my issues.

What's the most important thing in a 3D collectathon platformer? Tight controls and freedom of movement. Tight controls make platform challenges interesting and freedom of movement gives new and veteran players alike multiple ways to move around the stages. Not to mention that movement itself can be incredibly satisfying in of itself due to variety of moves you can pull off. Why I bring this up? Because those two [b]crucial[/b] concepts, I refuse to continue playing.

First off, the platforming is physics based. Because you're a box and you roll around the environment instead of having legs or something, not all jumps are consistent and it all depends on how you land, where you land, how steep is the slope and how fast you move. That means if you want to be fast you have no idea how high you'll jump, in what direction and how far it'll reach, resulting in very frustrating moments. It's hard to enjoy the game if you're so unsure of your own movement. To counterract this, the game brings you the "unbox" ability, which are disposable multi-jumps in the air that refresh back to full by collecting health crates or by reaching check points. Again, good idea on theory, but it has nasty side-effects.

Because you can make up to six jumps in mid-air, the level design suffered greatly as a result. Everything is too far away to accomodate this and most stages are just islands far apart with a singular obstacle course between each of them, making stages more linear. That "unbox" mechanic seems like a band-aid for the floaty controls and box-related platforming. In theory, wasting multiple jumps makes fighting enemies harder, but they aren't even that big of a threat, just a big annoyance. To beat them, you either get a weapon and shoot at  them or spam jump+attack near them to get rid of them. There's no challenge or point to it.

If your 3D platformer is hard to control or is inconsistent, it's a huge minus in my book. Even the amazing presentation won't salvage. You can argue how good the game is to actually master the controls, but if I can get into any other collectathon game like Super Mario 64 and have an amazing time with the controls in the first minutes, while at the same time still being challenged and impressed by the speed and flow of advanced moves hours in, I consider it a failure.

Then you listen to the music and realize that it's not that amazing. It sounds fake and bland. I have no idea how to put it into words.

So much potential. Squandered.

author: {'steamid': '76561198198945125', 'num_games_owned': 1497, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1552029819}
review:
A fun, short, lighthearted collect-a-thon adventure. Playing as a self delivering cardboard box is fun and creative, and once you get used to it the movement is a ton of fun to handle (except for a couple of times when you are forced to drive vehicles with tank controls). The challenge is not amazingly high, but it remains consistently enjoyable throughout. Unlocking and changing costumes and accessories for your character is also a nice touch, as you can make your box progressively more absurd as the game goes on.
 
The only questionable inclusion is the long-jump mechanic which tends to remove some of the difficulty from the platforming challenges. I personally had the most fun and found the most challenge in the missions where you weren't allowed to use it, so I generally ignored it when traversing the overworld. To be fair the small number of times you are allowed to use it before needing to either collect more powerups or return to a checkpoint limits its overall utility, but I still find it a bit of a crutch. I suspect the devs may have included this mechanic because the player (being a square box) sometimes gets stuck in the world geometry, and you need the extra boost to get going again.

Previous critics have been rather harsh on the game for its technical issues and crashes, but I don't think this is really warranted. Yes I did crash multiple times, especially when playing through proton on linux, but the game autosaves VERY frequently so I never ended up losing any progress. I think the low metacritic score the game has is undeserved, and for the price (just a few dollars) it is a solid entry in the mostly empty collect-a-thon genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018562297', 'num_games_owned': 498, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1546290782}
review:
Tried this one because it was in my discovery queue. Default controls are awful. Jump is universally space bar or A button on Xbox controller. Not this game. Had to use alternative control scheme #1 to get A to jump. The rest of the review mentioning buttons will be the Xbox controller.

Your health bar doubles as a mid-air jump count. You get a maximum of six health. Multi-jumping is a different key. Why not activate while in midair and using the jump button like any other game that multi-jumps? Use action should be B and attack action should be X or something and be context sensitive towards the situation like in other 3D games. Engage conversation with a trigger button? No thanks. That should be B. Attack? Can only slam the ground with X button.

Movement feels imprecise. Because you are controlling a cardboard box rolling around, you can't move in a straight line because box physics. When you want to stop, you have a little momentum going, and trying to stop makes you fight with the controls. Controlling the camera jumps all over the place. All these issues make it annoyingly difficult to land on platforms.

Driving controls are stupid too. Cars are very unstable and can't maneuver well without going in some direction you don't want it to go. I've played games with more stable car controls.

Refund.

Unreal Engine 4 game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030338011', 'num_games_owned': 898, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1544464810}
review:
A pretty unique plattformer in an open world, where you can solve many different quests and explore the landscape. 
It need's some time to get used to the movement, because you're a square and you can jump over huge distances, but once you get used to it, it's fun.
In the end I didn't got really into it, because most of the quests feel to easy, unsatisfying and I'm not really a jump and run type of gamer.
Overall a special jump and run / collect game, but from my perspective it is more made for kids, even if you can also enjoy it as an adult, if you like the world which it gives to you.

[b]6/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970282291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1545293570}
review:
This game is best compared to a variety of other collect-a-thon games like super mario, banjo tooie, crash bandicoot, etc. 
You play as a box and need to collect stamps, tape, outfits, and do quests for other boxes to do that.
The gameplay is fun, rolling around as a box is a bit unweildy at the beginning but it becomes more like rolling a lumpy marble than anything. I found that I spent most of the time jumping to get around.

The Good:
-Theres a box you can talk to at any time and he'll give you a helpful hint as to where the nearest collectible item is, this is especially useful when you only have a few ones left. What's not fun is when the camera doesnt show a lot of details, and you have to talk to him again to get a hopefully better angle.
-Movement is great and fluid! It's really easy to get around the map, there are fans that blow you to other places, and cars too.
-Items make a noise when you're close so you know that they are near, super useful!
-Great Controller support, seriously, if i switched from m+k to controller mid jump, it would register it. 
-SPLIT SCREEN!!!!

The Bad:
-It has no real soul, yeah the environments are cool but you're doing the exact same thing in them: collecting items and talking to people. This gets really boring after a while, as there isn't anything to really break up the monotony.
-Water is the only real hazard you have, as the Wildcard boxes are really easy to avoid.
-Not a lot of content in terms of gameplay. The worlds are mostly empty and not particularly pretty when viewed from afar.
-Unable to rebind keys...what???
-A game crashing glitch.


I like the game but unlike crash or banjo, it lacks content! I'm just collecting things! There are few enemies, puzzles, anything! This is STRICTLY a collect-a-thon.

I have a hard time hating the game because it's cute and well made. I don't hate it and I think its fun but at the same time it felt more like a chore to complete than an actual game. If you like collecting things you'll love this game, but up until about the last level, there wasn't a whole lot of interesting missions or puzzles to do. If steam asked whether or not I liked the game I'd say that I did, but it's asking me to reccomend it to others. I'm really on the edge of whether or not to give positive or negative because of this. I think for $10 or less, it's worth it. for $20, maybe not unless you really love the genre. 

I'd give this game a 5/10, but I don't really know if that's valid since there isn't really any other modern comparisons in the genre. I'm giving it a thumbs up because above all else it was at least entertaining and original, but I have a lot of reservations about the game and hope if they make a second one, they'll add more features.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117501009', 'num_games_owned': 824, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1536270239}
review:
A lovely chilling game that has a great potential in everything.
You're a box.. In an adorable world where there the concept of death doesn't exist even for your bitter enemies. You have to adventure around, doing few tasks along the way.. Mostly collecting stuff, racing, or just running around. Controls are a bit tricky at first but you will soon get used to them. You see, you're a box.. You don't have legs so you will have to jump around or just roll on your sides.. And as a box, you have a 90 degree edges everywhere making your movement a bit awkward.. You will be having a bit of a hard time at first moving around but it only takes an hour or so before you master it. Other than the tricky movement, the game is for casual players.. There are rarely any challenges involved.
Story is only there to give you an objective, not that amazing but something to make do. Gameplay is a lot of fun with all of these rolling and jumping around (And certainly, unboxing, which is a special move you will learn about as soon as you get into the game).

The game supports local multiplayer which is a lot of fun as well, i would even go further and say it is even more fun the campaign itself.. A lot of possibilities in this mode.

I definitely recommend this game to whoever find its visuals appealing and looking for a casual game to "chill".

€û Game time/length: ‚òê Really short ( 0 - 2 hours) | ‚òë Short ( 2 - 8 hours) | ‚òê Few hours ( 8 - 12 hours) | ‚òê Long ( 12+ hours) | ‚òë Endless

¬ß Bugs: ‚òê Game itself is one big BUG | ‚òê Bugs destroying the game | ‚òê Lot of bugs | ‚òë Few Bugs | ‚òê You can use them for speedrun | ‚òê Nothing

‚ú¶ Summary: Although I do not have many hours in this game, I can say that it is an interesting concept that was executed well. The game looks amazing and maintains a high FPS on max settings while I was playing it. Unbox also provides unique level designs that let you mindlessly explore to your heart's content, for a completionist it doesn't provide too many hours of gameplay. However, this game is not for everyone but for people who enjoy a rather at your own pace adventure game. In my opinion, this game is not worth 20$ because the story is not free-flowing and only appears at certain parts of the game while the rest is time spent golden duct tape and other collectibles. But, still gets recommended :).

author: {'steamid': '76561198280904665', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 810, 'last_played': 1532541128}
review:
You'd think a 3D Platformer where you rolled around as a cube would be god-awful, but surprisingly it's not. The atmosphere is great, the characters are all charming with unique personalities, the levels are for the most part well-thought-out and never feel empty, the 'unboxing' mechanic is interesting and what makes this game really stand out in my opinion. 

It's certainly not for everybody though. For one, it's incredibely easy; anything on a clock gives you way more than enough time and the very few times where something else could have been challenging, you respawn right where you left off making it a cake-walk. If you aren't a fan of 3D Platformer Collectathons you'll probably find it really boring. The items are well hidden with plenty of hints available when you get stuck, but if you don't care about that then there's not much for you here. As a big fan of the genre I enjoyed it a lot. I'd recommend downloading the demo and if you enjoy that you should definitely pick this game up, it's really a hidden gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136544947', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1529548366}

review:
Gioco bellissimo da provare assolutamente; questo √® forse il gioco pi√π bello e rilassante che abbia mai visto, senza contare la spettacolare grafica semplice ma d'impatto, le soundtrack di questo gioco sono molto rilassanti in particolare quella del secondo mondo, un altro punto a favore sono i personaggi che parlano in maniera simile ai personaggi di crok(gioco per ps1).
Non avete scuse per non giocare questo gioco se vi sembra che il presso su stream sia troppo alto, potete prenderlo su siti come istant gaming e altri a poco pi√π di 1 euro e 30 cent, ma il mio consiglio √® quello di aiutare gli sviluppatori e prenderlo a prezzo pieno o almeno scontato su stream, un'altro consiglio che vi d√≤ √® quello di giocare questo gioco con un controller stile Xbox o stream controller.
Nel caso il vostro PC non riesca a far girare bene questo gioco, lo si pu√≤ anche giocare su PS4, Xbox One e switch (io vi consiglio PS4 per il tipo di controller che ha).
L'unico difetto di questo gioco √® che ha una fine, infatti (almeno per me) √® uno di quei giochi che vorresti che non finisse mai.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044127578', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 1614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1494, 'last_played': 1594866921}
review:
[Though I gave this an unrecommend, I also recommend it.  My review explains why]

I want to recommend this game.  I rather loved this game.  There are two things that really bother me:
Bad hint system for the golden tape.
A bug they haven't been able to fix.

The game is super fun, and if you just want to mess around as a box flying through snowy mountains, a tropical island with a volcano, and a beach resort under construction, this is totally worth the buy.

Unfortunately, there is a tedious feeling when playing (it's a collectathon, so to be fair, that's what it was going for) with a poor hint system that sometimes gives a hint of a wall due to the camera's placement.

As for the bug, I have no chance to finish this game unless I get the chance to visit a friend (and I'm even skeptical of that)
On the third area (Isla Cartulina) one of the stamps cannot be obtained.  You are supposed to defeat 20 enemies in 1:40.  I can defeat 19 within approximately 30 seconds now due to the number of times I've played this.  The problem with that 20th enemy?  It does not spawn in.  I contacted the devs and they have said they can't replicate the bug, so it can't be fixed.  Be aware if you want to obtain 100%, there is a chance you cannot do so.

So even though I gave this review a no for recommendations, it's a great game that is worth a play if you're okay with it being unfinishable.

Update:
Since I last reviewed it, I have decided to give it a recommended instead.  For anyone who isn't a full achievement hunter, it's such a fun game.  Those who do, hope you don't get the same glitch I did.
