author: {'steamid': '76561198041108401', 'num_games_owned': 1219, 'num_reviews': 496, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1622750152}
review:
Totally awesome!
If you liked Banjo Kazooie, Donkey Kong 64, Super Mario 64 or any other 3D Jump n' Run with open world missions to do and funny stuff with a lot of happy positivity you will love this one!

"Unbox" is called the multijump you perform by unboxing your cardboard box out of an outer cardboard box √† la russian Matroska style and ejecting you in unknown heights! You can do this 6 times and as this is meanwhile also your health means that when you're at 0 Unboxes/health and an enemy hits you another time, your cardboard box pops up and you respawn at the next post box. But that is not throwing you back, because you keep the collectibles you got before, which is the main task here. You just lose a bit of way, but that is peanuts and negligible.

It is a physics based movement system powered by Unreal Engine 4. It makes really fun to just move around the beatifully made world. I had a big grin just moving around, trying to control the movement. It's a quite interesting movement, because the shape of your box with its edges and corners makes a difference for your speed and jump height, so you have to time your jumps well to reach the most speed or height. The movement reminds me of Marble Blast, but as a cube and not a marble.

Its very unviolent and appropriate for kids of every age in my opinion. What comes closest to violence are exploding TNT boxes blasting a hut or you are shot with colorful fireworks so that you have stars over your head. You beat other enemy boxes by falling on them as in Super Mario. In this game when you fall onto an enemy box they get yellow ducks hovering over their heads to indicate they are confused and don't attack you now. And what I find really cute and funny is that when you hit them again these ducks fall down on the ground to be 3D objects which can be pushed and shoved aside. When an enemy box or your box "dies" there pops up some styrofoam wisps from the damaged cardboard boxes, no blood, no "argh" sound, just a happy "poof", some styrofoam, that's it. Or the cardboard box gets wet, they don't like that, hehe.

The difficulty is easy. All controls are quickly understood, I felt home right at the start. It's an easy and relenting game. You will have much fun with movement mastering, challenge beating and exploring. Absolutely manageble for elementary school kids. Though there are some harder, but manageble challenges which want to be conquered. But all in all its an easy play without much tension or frustration but happy boxes, colors and music being everywhere (‚úø‚ó†‚Äø‚ó†)

I really enjoy it very much! Can only recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198314266610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 985, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 985, 'last_played': 1520790950}
review:
I'll come right out and say it: Unbox Newbie's Adventure is a lot better and a lot more enjoyable than I thought it'd be. If you love 3D platformers like I do and like games that are a bit silly, you'll most likely enjoy this game.

In Unbox, you'll play as a cardboard box who rolls (as well as a box can roll) and jumps around 3 large levels plus a hub world collecting Golden Tape (collectable coins) and Stamps (for when you complete challenges), find hidden Stamps throughout the world, and rescue other boxes called Zippies that are imprisoned in little cages. You can also customize your box's appearance.

Something I loved about the game is that you can get help if you're struggling to find the collectibles - the Golden Tapes are *everywhere* throughout the level (like hidden in trees, under bridges, on islands that in other games just seem like the background and nothing else, etc.). Help comes in the form of your box friend named Bounce showing you an actual screenshot of the area so you can hopefully recognize the surrounding areas and go get 'em.

I'm sure this game can be completed in far fewer hours than my playthrough. I logged 16 hours but that's because I felt compelled to play to 100% completion. Throughout my time with the game, I did not experience any clipping/graphic or control issues. Two thumbs up!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043642717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 812, 'last_played': 1518858062}
review:
Achievements: All possible.  A bit grindy-- there are over 800 collectibles to be found.  

Pros/Cons:
+ Lovable characters
+ Character customization
+ Unlockable hats/costumes/accessories/characters
+ 'Unbox' mechanic means you can jump 7 times in a row-- very fun to use.
+ Huge maps
+ Races/challenges
+ Vehicles
+ Hidden areas
+ Silly humor
+ Good music
+ Very forgiving with many well-placed checkpoints
+ There's an NPC to help you find collectibles.  
+ Collectibles have distinct audial cues.

- There was a puzzle area that twice left me unable to move-- meaning that I had to force quit the game and do the puzzle all over again.  
- Dismounting a sled upside down will crash the game.  
- The symbol for rockets will sometimes be left on your screen.  
- Controls feel clunky at first-- and its hard to be precise with jumps.  
- Vehicle controls were a bit awkward.
- The guide-arrow that leads you to NPCs does not lead you to the collectible finding NPC.  
- When you hide the guide arrow, talking to an NPC or reading a signpost will automatically bring it back up-- a little annoyance.  
- The game is 20$ and I only got ~14 hours of playtime, and most of that was collectible hunting.  The story could be rushed in ~5 or so hours.  

Overall: 
I am a sucker for 3D platformers.  This one is no exception.  It was nostalgic, it was goofy, it was fun.  Though the controls tended to feel a little clunky at first (playing as a rolling box and all...), they were surprisingly easy to get used to.  The unboxing mechanic was fun-- something I've not seen before.  Being able to jump so many times added a whole new level of maneuverability.  I definitely recommend this to anyone in the mood for a good 3D platformer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995451305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 804, 'last_played': 1615590082}
review:
A fun colourful collect-em-up, clearly taking inspiration from games like Super Mario 64 and Banjo-Kazooie. A number of Steam users have likened it to the N64 era, but to me, it gives off a bit of a GameCube vibe as well. Unbox has stunning visuals and big immersive worlds, putting me in mind of choice stages from Super Mario Sunshine, and the sea rig which serves as a hub world always makes me think of De Blob.

There were a few things I took issue with. Sometimes the game crashed when I sped up on downhill ice in the second level, and I feel like the third level could have been something other than a second island (though it was more interesting than the first). As for the collectables, there really wasn't a whole lot to get. I feel like the gold tape could have been cut down to 100 and you could have included a couple of other things. Time achievements for the race challenges would have also been a nice inclusion.

It's a great game and easy for the most part, with a few parts requiring a little more patience. It did seem like a lot was packed into just three levels. Five probably would have been enough. I personally would have liked a city level instead of two island levels, but I've had a lot of fun with it and look forward to a sequel, should that happen. If you enjoy games for the experience rather than the challenge, I definitely recommend this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076721797', 'num_games_owned': 915, 'num_reviews': 778, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1516685414}
review:
Honestly this game is surprisingly competent as a collectathon platformer given its incredibly kiddie nature and the wonky physics. The levels are massive but generally well-designed; the first two are sectioned off into smaller chunks and the third is so well designed that I don't even mind that it's more of one big area (though kind of sectioned off by the big mountain in the middle).

The game is pretty easy though; rarely is there any challenge to be found in the platforming itself. Aside from like, three challenges in the last world I never failed a single challenge and the ones I did fail there had more to do with the awful car controls than anything else. And there's a few platforming segments where you're not allowed to unbox, which can be a little tricky. I think that aside from the challenge time limits getting a bit more strict though there's basically no difficulty curve to this game. Heck, the first boss was the most difficult of the three and the tower in the first world is probably the hardest actual platforming segment in the game.

The unbox mechanic (basically just 6 extra jumps) is really interesting in terms of exploration though. It lets you get around places quickly but it's not unlimited, meaning you do have to scrounge for health to get your extra jumps back. And the way the game gives hints is pretty solid too, it doesn't directly tell you where stuff is but gives you a random camera angle of the location of what you want to find & expects you to figure out where it is. In some places it can be helpful, but there are other instances where it gives you a nondescript location and a useless camera angle which is basically no help to anyone. It's better than having to comb over the massive levels for that last gold tape though.

It does feel like the game improves over time, too. The third level is definitely the best but I'd say the second is also generally better than the first, which just feels a bit... barren in spots. All three levels could probably serve to be a bit smaller, the scenery gets a bit repetitive over time, but ehh. It's fun enough to play around in and find things even when you're not really being challenged and honestly sometimes you just want a dumb easy game to relax in.

Also yeah visually the game looks great, aside from the complete lack of any animations necessitated by literally every character being a box. Seriously, I don't think there's a frame of genuine animation in the entire game, just static objects moving around. And it's like, okay, but the world does feel a bit lifeless as a result, at times. The soundtrack is kind of... there. The main hub song and the first level's song are miditastic and sound kind of bad, the second level and third level have solid tunes that didn't get on my nerves after an hour or two of exploring though so I'd say they're alright. And the music does get slight variations depending on the vicinity of some NPCs, which is kind of a nice touch.

I'd say overall you could definitely do better in terms of 3D collectathons, and even with the three large levels the game is still fairly short - 100%ed it in about 11 hours according to steam, so. If you can get it on sale and want a relatively chill game to screw around in I'd say it's worth your time and money. It does feel like a lot of heart went into the game though it's also decisively not aimed at me but, yeah, it's alright enough. Has a demo too if you're really not sure, as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157201361', 'num_games_owned': 889, 'num_reviews': 795, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1515917120}
review:
I wanted this game to be a recommended due to its charm

-it had nice colors and visuals
-the hitboxes worked well
-they actually had implemented a destruction system in their cities while fighting
-interesting worlds

however I cannot give it a recommend rating due to many issues the game suffers from

first the glitches
-sometimes you get stuck where the only way to get out of it is to unbox (this happens when going uphill sometimes however it drastically happens more often when you are tethered to something)
-jumping off a sled while sideways or upsidedown causes game crashes
-sometimes the game dosent bring up button prompts (such as when completing a challenge usually it says press f but sometimes it dosent come up)
-in my first sit down when I had started up the game it had launched 2 instances of the game so I had annoying menu music playing in the background the whole time over the main game music (i exited the game and it brought up the second game which is how i found out that it had launched 2 clients)
- many checkpoints in the last level were faded out as if you were seeing them from far away even when right next to them

second the gameplay
-movement with rolling with a box while done realistically is kinda annoying making it both faster and easier to just jump everywhere the majority of the time
-the jumping mechanics are ok not bad but really not great either
-cars feel like you are driving on butter roads and it's flipping mechanic isn't really reliable often it would take 2-3 attempts to flip a car
-the worlds are really big but they feel empty because of the way the rewards are set up
-most of the npc's that talk dont even give any type of useful information in any way
-sometimes when done talking to someone or coming out of a shop or respawing i would be bounced away from where I should have been (usually off a cliff)
-the story is really slow in the beginning and it cant be skipped

basically this game had a TON of potential but it never really hit the right notes (like a typical middle school band playing the main theme from pirates of the carribean)

they had too much reliance on stamps where when you completed a quest you would recieve a stamp and a cosmetic and it took a certain amount of stamps to go and fight the boss and you would be able to do the next map there really felt like no reward from going and getting collectables

saving boxes gave 1 cosmetic if you save all of them per level
and WOW it take 200 thats right 200 gold tape to get 1 cosmetic item per level and the levels are actually quite big

you start with six unboxings (super jumps) it would have been smart if they would have tied all the cosmetics to the gold tape so every 20 gold tape you collected or so you would get a cosmetic and then they should have tied finding the purple future things with leveling up your jumping mechanic so you would really be searching for those to increase exploring potential that would have fleshed out the world and then also made saving the boxes from cages giving partial stamps or something like that and made npc's tell you hints about hidden items around the islands

so all in all not a terrible purchase but just not good enough for me for a recommended vote I hope they make a 2nd one that fixes those core issues

author: {'steamid': '76561198073959451', 'num_games_owned': 626, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1514084639}
review:
1 ‚Äì GENERAL 

Unbox: Newbie's Adventure is an open world platformer where you play as a box. Confusing enough? Wait for the story. You are the latest employee of a self delivery box company and you have to destroy the company enemy. How complex... 

I have to say that the game has surprisingly good graphics, despite some glitches here and there, some of those lead to gamebreaking bugs where you have to make a restart since you become stuck under or inside the scenario. 

The soundtrack suits the levels, but each soundtrack is short and repetitive. They end up abruptly and that makes it even worse. I've liked the "voice acting"‚Ä¶ ok, there's none tbh, but all boxes have a clear personality that we can associate with a voice. That was quite well managed by the team, and the final result is quite good. 

2- GAMEPLAY 

Jumping and make precise landings with a square box is quite tricky. The box never lands straight and the movement, as expected, is clunky. I know that the objective is that, but the controls are not easy to grasp, even with mouse and keyboard. With a controller is simply one of the worst experiences I had with a game. After you get the hang of it you start to take some fun from the game. It reminded me of Crash Bandicoot and overall, I've liked to explore and do all the missions. 

The missions were a bit repetitive, but I was never annoyed during them. Some are harder than others, but there's no sense of progression, some of the hardest are at the beginning, some of the easiest at the end. For instance, the first boss battle was the hardest one for me. 

Interestingly enough you can also drive cars. Don't ask you, as a box, can drive. Just do not think about it, ok? Driving is not a fun experience, since... well, ‚Ä¶ controls again. 

There are tons to explore at all levels, and a lot of collectables to find if you like to do that. I've finished the main campaign in about 8 hours, but you can easily take the double of the time finding all stuff and talking to everyone. The replay value of the game is here, in collecting everything. 

The game has some local co-op and you can play with 3 more friends if you wish. 

3 ‚Äì CONCLUSION 

The mix of genres in this game is interesting and I have to say that I've liked it. Beautiful and colourful landscapes, a fun open world to explore and much stuff to do. Very well conceived characters, lots of humour and references to pop culture. The controls made me not want to explore more and is certainly the worst of this game. Even so, if you find this game cheap, give it a go. It's not the best game in the world, but it's very competent and it did not disappoint.


As usual, some gameplay:

https://youtu.be/t-xOnH49BNI

author: {'steamid': '76561197964345647', 'num_games_owned': 921, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 1131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1131, 'last_played': 1514631132}
review:
I think this is one of the coolest 3D platforming adventures there is!  

I think it might be better than all the Tomb Raiders put together ;)


At first, this game was very frustrating, since you are a box...I do love unique and new game mechanics, so this game quickly grew on me :)

I adjusted the camera sensitivity down, which ended up making thing much better.  I also used a controller, which is probably ideal.

It is a unique and cute concept, basic 3D adventure, but as a bouncing box.  This puts an excellently unique and most times frustrating spin on the adventure/action classic.  You move unevenly and often bouncing in undesirable direction, which means you have to change your way of thinking about motion.

All in all, there is lots of game play here (This game is HUGE), great level design and a good amount of open world scavanging for hidden/scattered collectibles.

Humorous and playful, with beautiful graphic design...Definitely worth a play through!


ACHIEVEMENTS:  Mostly story based with a few collectibles, so not too difficult.  There are a few time trials, which I am not a fan of :(


[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31208751/]Please follow my Pixel Art Curation for other great games...[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198238170268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 1734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1688, 'last_played': 1516738754}
review:
I love this game for being a "gotta 100% it" and it reminds of other games in the same vein (Banjo, DK64) but I can't recommend due to my personal experience being ruined by a silly bug. The thing is, at some world (Parcel Peaks) there'll be a bug that won't register one (or more, like in my case) stamps you get, preventing you from getting 100% of the game.
I found out other people had this issue and the dev(s) is/are still working on it but we didn't see a reply about it for months. I hate to have unfinished/incomplete games, even more when it's not my fault they're like that. I think I'll have to restart the whole game to get all the collectibles again....
If you're a completionist, think twice before getting it, this game is fun but bugs like these make it a frustrating experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064624448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1520559555}
review:
Purchased a bundle for 2CAD and this game was the one i bought for, i wouldn't buy it at full price but for 10-15$ this game is much much fun ! it come with full controller support and hell i can say that after a big working say its a pleasure to relax on the couch playing Unbox ! Your kids will love the graphic and the music will probably make you crazy after an hour or two but mehh.. Turn off the music --> Open Spotify --> Search for "Relax and unwind" --¬≠> Press Play --> ENJOY !

I'd recomend this game to anyone who need some relaxation after his long working day [spoiler]  or every parent who want a break from their kids for[strike] 1-2h [/strike] 3-4HOURS LOL[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198000959334', 'num_games_owned': 1304, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1524360615}
review: One of my favourite youtube videos happens to be VideogameDunkey's video on banjo kazooie, because its like he took the words right out of my mouth. Unbox reminds me of one of the last things he says in that video, that banjo kazooie is a game that makes you happy when you play it. Im a person that is typically too big for their britches and is a heavy critic, complaining about even the smallest detail because i care so much for this medium. But theres just nothing i can focus on in this game because im simply having too much fun flying around the extremely well crafted worlds and laughing at the silly jokes, just generally having a good time. I owe it to the creator of this game to try and make it more popular, because the lack of exposure this recieved saddens me. Pick this up if you enjoy platformers, I garuntee you wont be disapointed.

review:
Awesome platformer! Great box gameplay and a huge world for exploring. What do you need more? If you like 'A Hat in Time' relaxing gameplay - buy 'Unbox'.

Pros:
+Gameplay
+Cute graphics

Semi-Cons:
Voice acting a bit annoying
Music is a bit monotonous
You need to get used to control the box (because physics)

Nothing about the hard cons.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065277628', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1510415262}
review:
I enjoyed the game personally. To put things in perspective of the old number out of 5 system:

Gameplay: 3.5 / 5, Satisfying to knock enemies of the map with ground pounds.
Controls: 2 / 5 (Keyboard, mouse),  4.5 / 5 (controller) Definitely use a controller.
Story: idk it was there, 2 / 5
Replayability: 3.5 / 5, as soon as I got one gold tape it was over for me. I had to 100% the game (Took about 9 hours)
Graphics: 4 / 5, looks solid, runs well on my laptop with high settings in 1920 x 1080p
Sound: 4.5 / 5 Great soundstrack. Characters were funny sounding boxes all with their own intriguing personalities.

Comments: There are a lot of references and is a definite throwback to the older style of collectathon platformer style games of the 90's, early 00's eras.

Overall:
If you like platforming collectathons buy it full price, or other wise get it on sale. Definitely worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160064095', 'num_games_owned': 1273, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1659683572}
review: One of the better platformers on Steam, but that is saying something. The awkward controls, mediocre camera and annoying sound and dialogue kind of spoils what is a beautiful, colourful and original platformer. There are some interesting ideas, but the gameplay just feels a little one dimensional. It feels like a [really, really] poor man's Banjo Kazooie. If it had that extra bit of polish, it would be one of the best, but it is not really that fun. Get it on special, don't really think it is worth $20.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993565027', 'num_games_owned': 624, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1504238907}
review:
Only an hour isn't generally a good way to know if a game is right for you, I know, so take my review with a grain of salt.

The game is pretty, I'll give it that. The controls are actually pretty solid, and I had a lot of fun navigating the world. That's probably why I played as long as I did. 

Many things turned me off from the game though. About 20 minutes is spent explaining the *incredibly* simple game mechanics, that could be shown off in-game, or even just a box popping up to the side, if the devs really wanted to ensure I wasn't confused.

As the game progressed, it never let go of my hand.

"Remember to save the Zippies!" it says, over and over until I flip the switch to the Zippy cage I'm next to, thus, removing any real feel for discovery, or even that I'm doing anything for myself.

"I hear a stamp nearby!" it also repeats, again, removing any personal discovery I felt.

This sort of went on and on, with lots of hand holding.

TL;DR

I was expecting a fun collect-a-thon platformer, I got a childs game instead.

review:
Tons of banjo-kazooie/collectathon fun. If you like those old Ty/Mario 64/Sunshine kind of games then you'll have a lot of fun with Unboxed. My only complaint is with the painfully slow intro/tutorial sequence where the dialog box pops up every 5 seconds.. the game isn't that complicated to warrent a step by step tutorial lol. They should have just had the dialog on the screen without pausing the game so you can just rush through it if you know what's going on.
I love that you can collect outfits for your box haha. Just beat the game 100% and loved every minute of it (after the tutorial ended).

author: {'steamid': '76561198021489268', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1501867733}
review:
Presentation

First up, presentation. This game call itself a 90's style 3D platformer and I believe they really nailed that feel. It feels like a nice modern version of games like Super Mario 64 or Banjo Kazooie. The art style is a nice mix between cartoony and realistic. It's made in Unreal so the textures look great and as shiny as ever. The music in this game is a real joy to listen to, particularly on the first world. The level paradise isles has a lot of steel drum music which is so reminiscent of Super Mario Sunshine. The particle effects are pretty lovely as well, and there a good amount of them with all the explosive boxes lying around and the sheer amount of enemies as well. The only real negative I have is the "voices" of the other boxes, it does the thing where they just kind of make noises instead of saying words and I don't really like that. Overall though, super nice presentation.

Gameplay

For Gameplay, I'm a little mixed. So the basis of this game is you're a box that rolls around, and yes that doesn't really make sense, as well as jump and unbox yourself, which acts as an additional jump. Your main goal is to do missions that enable you to collect stamps, this game's version of stars, and once you have enough stamps you can fight the boss for each level. There's also gold tape lying around everywhere which you can collect to cash in for customization. Very simplistic, again it's set up very similar to Super Mario 64, more or less a clone of it. Most of my problems lie in the movement. I feel the controls are a little bit sluggish, partially because you are moving around a box, but you don't move immediately when you push forward and you don't stop immediately either. That sorts of makes sense to an extent, but it is just hard to be precise with the controls because you are a box and when you land you rarely land flat on one side so you kind of bounce in any direction. I guess that is some of the charm of the game, but I'm just kind of meh on it. Another problems with the movement is that since you really don't roll very well, the only real way to most quickly is to just jump around all the time. I do want to explain the unbox system as well. You have a number in the bottom left that serves as your health and your second jump. The number goes as the way to 6. So you can possibly have six extra jumps that allow you to reach higher places or traverse big bodies of water. There's health boxes around to replenish this number, plus you can go to a checkpoint to get it back to full automatically. I really like this system, and it makes the game far more enjoyable. The last thing I want to touch on is the missions. While they are nothing revolutionary, they are varied enough to keep you going. They can range from your typical fetch quest, to a race, to destroying enemies, to scaling buildings, and much more. Overall for gameplay, I like certain aspects, but there's a good amount of stuff that I don't like as well.

Content

Content is where this game falls flat in my opinion. There's 3 worlds, each with 18 stamps. You need 10 stamps to fight each boss. To just beat the game without collecting all the stamps on average takes a little less than 5 hours. To 100% it probably will takes about 8 hours. Considering this game is 20 bucks, that is just too steep for the amount of content. There is a fair amount of customization for you character, but nothing unheard of. Another problem I have in this game is the story. The jyst of the story is some boxes have gone rogue and you're sent in to destroy them and fix everything more or less. When I do missions, I don't feel like I'm accomplishing anything though, I don't really feel like I'm progressing the story. Most of the missions don't have to do with the story at all, they are literally just to collect stamps. Even when you beat a boss, it doesn't feel like I've toppled anything or saved the island. The story isn't the main draw to this game to be fair, this game is far more about the platforming, but I would have liked to see a little more to it.

Overall this is a pretty game, with some decent platforming and gameplay, but it lacking in the content department. I don't think this game is bad by any means, but I wouldn't recommend paying full price for this game. Definitely one that you should pick up on sale or if you see it in a bundle. I give this game a 63 out of 100.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064308604', 'num_games_owned': 716, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1495951938}
review:
I thoroughly enjoyed this ode to 90's collect-a-thon platforming. The challenges themselves sometimes got a little repetitive, but like many of the games this is clearly an homage to, it's the world, level design, story, and dialogue that kept me playing. 

Especially the world design, which really is top notch. A lot of care was clearly put into making interesting paths that loop around and cross over one another like spaghetti, which makes the more open hub worlds actually work instead of needing more linear levels like a lot of collect-em-ups do. I kept finding new paths and things to grab in areas I thought I had already cleared whenever I approached them from a new angle, and that can't be easy to pull off from a design standpoint.

Between that and the clever bits of dialogue and gameplay references, this comes off almost as charming as the platforming giants it's giving the wink and nod to. Favorite joke of the game was the clothing store, "Swift Tailoring". It's delivered so straight that it actually took me a few times hearing it to get it, and when I did I burst out laughing at both the game's and my own stupidity. 8/10 would shed soggy cardboard skin again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968260552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1497122592}
review:
A fun little indie 3D platformer. The kind game you can kick back and relax with. For the most part it's easy, but some puzzles are quite challenging. Not frustratingly challenging, though. The kinda challenging where you don't rip your hair out after the billionth time you died, but the kind you have to ponder for a moment 'till you figure out the solution or manage to time something perfectly.

Anyhoo, if you're someone who likes to collect stuff in games(I sure am), this scratches that itch very nicely. The controls are ok and the visuals fit the theme nicely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003232053', 'num_games_owned': 2198, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1496708067}
review:
The best part about Unbox are the references to other platformers and games in general. 
Unbox as a game itself, can be reduced to a game that balances a protagonist with akward control, with a simple gameplay and barely any challenges. 
If you are one of those completionists, with the urge to find 100% of everything, Unbox might entertain you with its open world. If you are not, my rating is 5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040842672', 'num_games_owned': 3000, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1495389588}
review:
Unbox is a traditional 3D platformer that tries very hard to imitate the classics of the 90s (Mario 64, Banjo-Kazooie, etc.). You play as Newbie, a sentient delivery box working for GPS (Global Postal Service). You jump and roll your way through three open maps (+ hub world) and collect as many stamps and other collectibles as possible.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
Unbox looks nice and colorful. The models are fairly simple but still look decent enough.

On a technical level the game is not quite as impressive. Some areas (especially large indoor sections) suffer from slowdowns and the rather extreme LOD popping is often distracting, particularly during cutscenes.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The sound effects are decent enough. I wasn't a big fan of the music or the "voice acting", however. The music is ok but extremely repetitive. Like in many classic platformers there is no real voice acting, just gibberish voices. Unfortunately, in Unbox many of the character voices are extremely annoying.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Gameplay-wise Unbox is a very traditional platformer with some extremely simple combat. The only real innovation is the ability to unbox. Unboxing let's you jump again in mid-air and you can do this as long as you have health points left. In practice this makes you extremely mobile as health refills are easy to come by.

The levels themselves are pretty open and you can move around them quite freely. The main goal in each level is to collect stamps. These can be won through various challenges (races, puzzles, fights etc.) or found hidden in the scenery. While the maps themselves are reasonably well-designed, many of these challenges aren't particularly fun or interesting.

In addition to the stamps, each level has a huge amount of other collectibles, but these are purely optional and don't seem to provide any in-game benefit. At the end of each level there's also a simple bossfight.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
Overall Unbox is a rather easy and casual game once you learn the controls. However, the difficulty of the challenges is all over the place and some of them can be fairly challenging.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
On a gamepad the controls were passable but not great. You control a box so understandably your movement is bit awkward. The controls aren't very precise either but at least you have the ability to unbox which is usually enough to recover from mistakes.

The vehicle controls on the other hand are truly atrocious and the vehicle physics are terrible. Luckily there are only a few sections in the game where you actually have to use the vehicles.

[h1]Story and Writing[/h1]
The story and writing are both very poor. I don't except a great story in a platformer, but the story in Unbox is particularly bad. The characters are all extremely uninspired and the constant bad jokes and pop culture references get old fast.

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
The game is reasonably polished. I did have one crash while restarting a challenge and the physics can be rather wonky at times.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
Personally I feel that Unbox is a rather poor imitation of the classic platformers. The controls are awkward, the story is rubbish and the gameplay isn't particularly good either. I wouldn't recommend the game unless you have already played the aforementioned classics to death.

I played through the main campaign but didn't bother collecting all the stamps or golden tapes. This took me around 6 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031273221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1493998438}
review:
TLDR edition: Overall, it's a fun, cheap, colourful and interesting modern take on the classic platformer genre, and even though I've barely started it, I've had well worth the sale price from it, and have many more hours of enjoyment to go!


Pros:

- Cute, clean and colourful graphics
- Real throwback to the 90s
- Large worlds to explore
- Lots of collectables
- Varied content between puzzles, exploration, platforming and challenges/mini-games
- Fairly easy and casual experience


Cons:

- Rolling and jumping mechanics can be clumsy and hard to direct
- No real story or purpose to what you're doing (goes with the genre though)


Full Length Review: 

After having an itch for a 90s platformer rear its head in recent months, and after being put off Yooka-Laylee because of its price and length, I saw Unbox on a bundle site sale at what worked out to be about ¬£2. So I took a gamble.

My initial impression was of the voice acting. Garbled talk just as in YL and Banjo Kazooie in the old days. I had to chuckle given this was my YL replacement. I did the quick tutorial and then worked on the first world.

The game has 3 distinct worlds plus a central hub world. Each world have various collectables to gather in order to progress to the next one, and eventually 100% the game if you wish. I am currently at the end of the first world and have found most of the hub world's collectables after about 5 hours of playing. Each world has a varied aesthetic and is pretty large - far bigger than I'd have expected.

The mechanics do grate on me after a while, with it being difficult to direct the rolling and jumping aspects. I like that you can double jump, up to a maximum of 6 times before having to refill health (basically a charge mechanic). Health boxes are plentiful and checkpoints are everywhere, which also fill health to max. Basically the 6 charge is your limit to attempt a particular jump or to land somewhere.

In terms of content; you have your exploration with 'golden tape' to collect. 200 in each world. Then you have mystery diary entries to find; about 5 in each world from what I can tell. Finally, you have 'Stamps' which are awarded by solving puzzles or completing challenges - little "race" types where you have to deliver a letter across the island in 5 minutes or fight 20 enemy boxes in 2 minutes etc. Unlock enough of these Stamps and you can fight the world's boss and progress to the next world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008549198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 576, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1494061375}
review:
Pretty original open-world cartoonish game with cute landscapes. It takes a while to get used to the character's odd responsiveness and the multiple jumps (with a stock of jumps that also act like life points), but then it's all good.

Just 2 big weak point: 
- vehicles physics is really painful (for instance, if you barely scratch a wall, the car will stop as if it hit a 100 tons block of concrete), racing with those is horrible, with the ridiculously short timers making it even more painful. Thankfully, you don't have to use them much so it's not too bad
- mouse sensitivity is too low, even when set to the max, so the camera is a bit of a PITA

And 2 slightly weak points:
- the "plot" is ridiculous, with some dialog being only partially skippable
- you can't save whenever you want (but there are many save points scattered around the world, so that's not really an issue)

author: {'steamid': '76561197972597325', 'num_games_owned': 895, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 990, 'last_played': 1547536266}
review:
Excellent game. It's cute and has some quirky humour. I had no issues with the controls or the game ingeneral.

The graphics are excellent. The audio is good for the most part, although the music can become repetitive but serves its purpose.

Multiplayer is enjoyable with friends, could do with more maps however.

Unfortunately the camera can be a bit daft (although this is just a byproduct of 3D platformers).

I would definitely pay full price for this game, check out the demo and go from there.

If you enjoyed this game, check out: Poi, The Last Tinker, Yooka Laylee, A Hat in Time and Skylar & Plux.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042241093', 'num_games_owned': 794, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1518913567}
review: This has been one of my favourite games i've played for a while, the mechanics are a bit strange and sometimes the jumping is awkward or frusturating, but it runs just fine (Intel HD 3000). The game also has local 2-4 player multiplayer, I havn't played much of it but it seems like a lot of fun. I would like to point out that I did get this game at a large discount (around $0.40) however, that being said, I would definitely pay full price for it. I hope someone found this review helpful, if not, oh well and I wish I could say more, but I have only played for about 2 hours with a friend who also bought it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025034462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1501119562}
review: I'm not done playing this game yet, but I think I've seen enough to recommend it. It's a fun game about platforming around and collecting collectibles by completing various objectives. However, you're a box, so platforming that would be really easy in other games is suddenly extremely difficult. This actually makes the game more enjoyable, and I found myself getting a good feeling simply from landing my box perfectly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109081592', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1597976978}
review: This game is unrealistically cute. Its like Little Big Planet meets Super Monkey Ball on an open world platform. You're a box, so you move as a box would if it were sentient...corners and such. The challenges aren't too hard, but just difficult enough to make me feel like I'm actually getting better at the game. Beautiful landscapes and funny dialogue. this game is so much fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029193240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 711, 'last_played': 1492541371}
review:
Certainly one of the more enjoyable games I played in quite some time!
You play as a Box (which you can customize in several fun ways) and you do little missions as collect Stamps, Golden rolls of tape and save boxes that have been caged by the big bad Boxes!
Spend about 10 hours in right now, just rolling around, collecting stuff, driving cars & sleds and I enjoyed every minute of it!

Such a simple and casual game, it's so much fun! 
10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198076300339', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 705, 'last_played': 1492212286}
review:
[h1] Tenerezza in Scatola [/h1]

Unbox √® un gioco molto semplice, da qualcuno potrebbe essere relegato a gioco per bambini, ma a mio parere pu√≤ giocarci anche un 80enne. Come da intestazione il gioco straripa di tenerezza, partendo dalle scatole che sono i persognaggi del gioco e il loro simpaticissimo linguaggio (che strappa un sorriso con ogni nuova scatola che si incontra).
I controlli sono ridotti al minimo (salto, doppio salto "unboxing" fino a 6 volte di fila, schianto alla crash bandicoot per eliminare alcuni nemici o premere pulsanti) il che rende il gioco rilassante e concede pi√π libert√† alla vista per individuare tutti i collezionabili presenti nelle 4 mappe (molto grandi).
La longevit√† non √® elevatissima, la tenera avventura della nostra scatola [spoiler] semi-aliena [/spoiler] dura circa 5 ore se vengono ignorati i vari collezionabili, invece includendo la raccolta di quest'ultimi si possono superare le 10 ore di gioco, nel mio caso 11.8 ore completando tutti di achievments di steam.
Gioco che merita, consigliatissimo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198207370923', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 409, 'last_played': 1678984011}
review: One of the most fun games i've played in quite a while!The story isn't very long but you'll be searching for hours to find that last piece of gold tape or the final stamp in a level!Sometimes that's a bad thing though.It can get frustrating trying to find enough stamps to advance the story.But enough of the bad stuff!It really is overall a very enjoyable experience if you love collecting things!Also about the story,It's really well done and there's some honestly surprising twists and hilarious jokes!And you would die before you count all of the amazing references and in-jokes!I highly recommend this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005798928', 'num_games_owned': 938, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 968, 'last_played': 1491464664}
review:
it's a great game with interesting enough worlds to make collecting everything a fun option. the story is sweet, the graphics are unusually great and the performance is wonderful. 

the gameplay is very unique - i can see many people being put off of it at first because you're rolling a box that doesn't stop on command so your jumps and movements can be infuriating. the game caters to this and once you get used to it, the game becomes a lot more fun: unboxing gives you incredible jumping powers that let you explore the world freely.

the story missions mainly consist of the same things done slightly differently but it's still relatively fun because of the totally different landscapes they reside in.

It's undoubtedly a kids game but you can still learn to love the artstyle and gameplay as an adult.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057218732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1491390039}
review:
[h1] Scatole, tante, TANTE scatole.	[/h1]

[i] Unbox	[/i] fa parte di quella stretta categoria di giochi scoperti "per caso", e in questo caso il "per caso" (troppi caso, proprio a caso...) √® rappresentato dal buon Sputafuoco, che mi ha fatto scoprire questa piccola perla grazie ad un bundle assai economico. 
Non posso non valutarlo positivamente, e mi rattrista il fatto che un titolo cos√¨ divertente e scanzonato sia passato cos√¨ in sordina, eccetto per qualche testata non proprio conosciuta che ci ha buttato giu un due righe a riguardo: con uno score di 68% su Metacritic (ben pi√π alto per quanto riguarda l'opinione del pubblico), [i] Unbox	[/i] √® un classicissimo platform 3D nel quale ci muoveremo all'interno di enormi livelli pieni zeppi di sfide e collezionabili da raccogliere. Tutto regolare fino a qui. La trovata simpatica sta nell'impersonare una scatola  che dovr√† sconfiggere il classico cattivone a capo della classica banda di sgherri cattivoni chiamati "Wild Cards". Il gameplay √® ridotto all'osso, non avremo movenze particolari o mosse sbloccabili durante il corso dell'avventura, e dovremo accontentarci del classico tasto per saltare e di una feature complementare ad esso, ossia il tasto dell'unboxing. Premendo LB (prendo come riferimento il pad della Xbox One) infatti potremo spiccare un'ulteriore salto, balzando fuori a mo' di matrioska dalla precedente scatola per spiccare un salto pi√π alto, e di fila al massimo sei: questo tasto sar√† fondamentale per poter raggiungere zone altrimenti inacessibili con la semplice pressione del salto normale. Oltretutto, con il tasto B, ci potremo schiantare atterra per compiere azioni contestuali o per stunnare i nemici. Tutto qua. Ma non √® un "tutto qua" polemico, questo gameplay ridotto all'essenziale √® estremamente divertente, e sopratutto non stanca troppo a causa della longevit√† non troppo elevata, che si attesta pi√π o meno sulle 6-7 ore di gioco. I collezionabili poi non mancheranno, come non mancheranno le customizzazioni della nostra scatoletta, e dalle sopracitate 6 o 7 ore di gioco si arriver√† a pi√π di 10 se vorrete completare il gioco al 100%! 
Insomma, un gioco semplice ma efficace, che vale il prezzo che costa. Amanti dei platform, fatevi sotto, Unbox non vi deluder√†!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038056805', 'num_games_owned': 3183, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1652816694}
review:
I can't stand Goat Simulator. As a gamer, I think it's an idiotic sandbox that isn't that fun. As a parent, I don't want my kid playing it, but I don't want to be "that dad" who blocks my kid from playing a game without offering a substitute. I can't tell you how happy I was when I found Unbox. Unbox is a kid-friendly version of Goat Simulator, while being interesting enough for me to join in and play a few multiplayer rounds with him.

Controls can be difficult to get used to since, well, you're a box and the physics for walking as a box are pretty spot-on. It's a challenge, but a nice challenge. Graphics are really nice for an indie studio, everything felt really smooth. Quests are  simple for the most part, and the tutorial is great to get you acquainted. My only gripe was the really weird initial controls, but you can remap them if you want. Level design actually had a Super Mario Sunshine feel to it, to me it felt like a Saturday morning as a kid.

I don't recommend this game for most adults unless you [i]really[/i] like Goat Simulator, if you do, then this is a refreshing take on the goofy sandbox genre. I believe this game is much more suited for parents who are introducing their kids to Steam gaming and are looking to find a family-friendly title in the mix, and it does it's job well.

review:
This game is the story of three or four really good level designers that wanted to make a game and then figured out they can only really make really good levels so they got their dog to design the characters and their cat to compose the music.

Lucky for you guys exploring maps is my fetish. Still pretty weird that the game takes like 20 minutes to start up though.

review:
This game is fun, but there are a few problems.

1. The driving mechanic is bad. You need to use the mouse to steer, you shoud make it A and D.
2. It gets boring after 1 to 3 hours of one sesion play
3. The customization is disapointing, I was under the impression that you could change the eyes, mouth, etc

The game is very fun, and I think that its full worth the initial price

author: {'steamid': '76561198012780937', 'num_games_owned': 1188, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1479195009}
review:
Gonna give this one a tentative recommendation. If you grew up on Rareware games and similar 3D platformers like I did and are looking to relive some of that sweet sweet nostalgia, no need to keep reading, this game will absolutely scratch that itch. If you're still skeptical however, read on, because there are a few quirks to Unbox that may make or break your overall enjoyment of the game.

The first thing that I would like to point out, is that, despite the fact that Unbox successfully capitalizes on N64 and early Playstation platformer nostalgia better than any game since... Well probably Psychonauts... It still feels like a new-generation game. The game environments have more in common with the likes of Far Cry and Uncharted than they do with Banjo Kazooie for example, and although the level design is still highly detailed and very good overall, there is an element of realism to the game enviroments that is not shared by the games that Unbox has been frequently compared to. There are pros and cons to this increased world size and realism, one major pro being that the game is a satisfying length and feels full of content even though the story only takes you to three different locations. The drawbacks are most notably that the stamps needed to progress through the story can be hard to find, environments aren't varied enough and ultimately will end up being boring after spending some time in each, and platforming is a little quirky even beyond the obvious caveat that you play as a box and, as such, control like a box.

That said, one of the biggest strengths of the game for me was the actual controlling of the box. A lot of people have pointed this out as a con, but to me it actually adds a nice challenge to the experience. None of the platforming is particularly difficult, and when it is harder than normal checkpoints are placed very generously, so the bulk of the challenge comes from how the rolling box actually handles. I found the controlling of the box to be satisfying and realistic even though some players might find it clunky. The movement is held back a little bit by an unorthodox control system (at least with an Xbox controller which I personally used for the whole game), but given that there is only about 4 different functions, the control scheme will very quickly become familiar to you, even if it isn't perfect.

This brings me to, in my opinion, the biggest shortcoming of Unbox, the "minigames". I call them that because I don't know what else to compare it to in other similar games. Basically the story is progressed by collecting stamps, anybody who played Mario 64 or Banjo Kazooie will be familiar with this as they are functionally the same as Stars or Jiggys in those games (respectively). However, despite them serving the same function in progressing the story as more are collected, the way these are actually collected is different. In each of the three worlds, recurring characters will give you "missions" which are essentially just minigames. These can be fun at first but the real downfall of these minigames is that they are effectively exactly the same on all of the three worlds you travel to. You eventually come to expect exactly what each character will ask of you. There are some outliers but for the most part these become quite the grind. They are also not particularly difficult in and of themselves and the difficulty instead is creating by imposing an arbitrary time limit on almost all of these excursions. One of the worst offenders is a racing minigame in which the player is tasked with just getting from point A to point B in a certain time frame, sometimes these races include cars as well which just seems like a clunky and unnecessary addition to the game, and the game would've been significantly better without the inclusion of this mechanic. Some stamps can still be collected by just stumbling upon them or solving puzzles like you would in Mario 64 or most Rare games, and these are definitely the highlights of this stamp collecting aspect of the game, but that said, these stamps tend to be last resorts as there is no way to find them in the giant worldspaces other than stumbling upon them, whereas instead you can be directed to the minigame options with a giant arrow.

Overall, despite these flaws, my opinion of Unbox is that it is definitely worth it if you're looking for a potent dose of nostalgia with some modern flair and mechanics. This blend of new and old works more often than it doesn't, and the game succeeds through vibrant worldspaces, unique platforming and movement, and entertaining characters, even if it is brought down a little bit by it's core stamp collection mechanic. I got this game for $10 in the Humble Bundle and definitely think that is a fair price, so keep a lookout for it on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014932334', 'num_games_owned': 2698, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1482943944}
review:
Almost a 3D Platformer throwback masterpiece. It's got the graphics, the level design, the game structure, the writing, the atmosphere. The game is well balenced with a good difficulty and a decent amount of content.

But the game has you controlling a box. Rolling a box around is the least satisfying movement mechanic I think I've ever experienced in a 3D game. The camera bobs constantly as the corners of the box flip, and the physics are fully fleshed out in that concept. This all gives me a huge headache - the camera bouncing looks terrible, and the boxes are very difficult to control. The "jumping" is more of a "throwing yourself into things" in the vein of joke 3D platformers like Goat Simulator, and it wasn't satisfying to control there and it's not fun here.

If the developers ever make a mode where the boxes have legs and it controls closer to your usual 3D game, I'd happily recommend the game again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028321111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1482965441}
review:
My first review/opinion on Steam and got to say what a game! If you love platformers, love quirky games then this is a must!   


You play as a box and your job is to save the company which is called GPS. Like all platformers of yesteryear you do this by exploring the world, collecting things, doing challenges and finding secrets. As this is a game about boxes the main things you will collect is cellotape and stamps. Collecting 200 cellotapesin in each world gives you new clothing for your box and collecting stamps lets you fight bosses and progress. In each level you can also rescue boxes that are trappped in for extra stamps. The wolrds look beautiful and well detailed with lots going in and teh humour is fantastic. 

I've only couple of hours so far but I haven't come across any problems and really don't have anything negative to say. So if you love  fun, funny, quirky games or platformers this is one you should play! If you don't find this adorable and cute then there is something wrong with you lol.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995914916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1482461113}
review: fun and challenging. Solid controller support.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970678144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 20, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1711571605}
review:
This game is a lot of fun!  I particularly enjoy playing it with my children who enjoy the challenge and particular, hunting down all the tape!  The difficulty is just right, a challenge, but not too hard, so that you are determined to get those tricky hidden things. 

The concept is novel and you have to love the faces on the boxes.  If you can pick yourself this game up with a discount then you are getting a bargain.  Have it on your pc at Christmas time and it will keep the kids quiet when they have done with unwrapping all the presents!

author: {'steamid': '76561198241683356', 'num_games_owned': 87, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 448, 'last_played': 1481601885}
review:
Unbox is the kind of game you play when everything stressful is going on in your life. The cute visuals and music help get across what kind of game this is going to be. From talking to the diffrent boxes, finding collectibles, to exploring the diffrent worlds, this games is one I can play and immideatly have a nice day. But is it fully worth it?
PROS
- The worlds are massive. I found myself exploring each world for hours in hopes of finding new secrets. The detail in them is incredible, and they immideatly get the theme across.
-The music, while simplistic, is nice. It reminds me a lot of the 3d Mario games. Each song is fitting for each of the worlds. Altough for some it can be a little repititve. 
- Each character has a unique personality that let you know rightoff the bat what kind of box they are. Wheter they are a jolly happy box, a worker box, or a possible homicidal bunny box, each of them has something that makes you like them
- All of the challenges ar simple and fun. None of them felt unfair, and I looked foorward to seeing what the next would bring to the table. From time trails, to exploring the maps for collectibles, each challenge requires you change playstyle in some way shape or form.

CONS
- The physics in this game, while functional, have a tendency of being a little messy. I found myself getting stuck a few times, and even had to restart a challenge or two due to some weird physics glitch.
- While I was not expecting Metal Gear levels of storytelling in a game like this, the game could have been even better with more bits of story. This become evident towards the end where everythig just becomes rushed because they needed a reason for boss battles.
- While I love collect-athon games, this is one of the weaker ones. Outside of a few cosmetic unlocakables, there is no real reason I found for collecting all of the tape and stamps outside of getting 100%.
- The combat in this games is just very clunky. It ranges from being simplistic to frutrating. You will go from slamming enemies, to doggin missles that range from being slightly annoying, to instant kills. This is especially proven in the final boss fight, where I found myself getting 1 hit KO like 20 times.
-Lastly, the game almost feels too short. With only three worlds and a hub world, the game almost feels incomplete in some way. I feel that the game would have benfited from having an addotional two worlds to make the journey feel satisfying.

While these cons may seem frustrating, I still had fun with the game, and look forward to whatever the developers have next in store. If a sequel were to be made and fix some if the issues this first one had, I feel we will have a good tribute to the old N64 collector games. While $16 may seem like a lot and I would personally wait for it to go on sale, if you have the money and are looking for a relaxing fun time, get Unbox!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002391387', 'num_games_owned': 812, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1481504378}
review: If you're really hard-up for an open-ish platformer, fine. But be warned - the camera is awful. the controls seem to be intentionally made to disorient you (since you're a box, you move by rolling around - which leads to a kind of erractic lurch since boxes have sharp corners). the jumping is slippery and oversensitive. and it seems to be operating at a third grade reading level, which is maybe fine for third graders? but i can't sit through that much sacchrine, slow moving, over-explained storybook stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025205047', 'num_games_owned': 1413, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 542, 'last_played': 1563497068}
review:
Picked this up in a Humble Bundle and I'm glad I did. I'm enjoying exploring the world, accidently blowing up the box's houses and collecting stamps. Only complaints: Wish I could adjust the dialogue speed to be faster, and jumping can be a bit impercise which is frusterating when trying to get all the tape rolls. I'm only on the first world, but I've enjoyed what I've played of it so far.


Edit: Upon Further play I have found that the music is extremely repetative in the winter zone, to the point where I've had to completely turn it off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019163551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1486236976}
review:
I like this game, I like the genre it throws back to, if there were MORE available in this genre on steam (and in a modern gaming enviroment in general) would I reccomend it? Well, I don't know. 

I wonder if the conceit of "sentient cardboard boxes" was an artisic choice, or one of convienience, so to avoid doing animations and designs for the dozens of characters that appear in this game. None of the characters here are memorable, visually or otherwise. Unbox gains nothing from it's central conceit that wouldn't have been worth sacrificing for compelling character design. 

The worlds are QUITE massive and lushly designed, there's a lot to see and do and the game is really charming for what it is. "Unboxing" as a mechanic, seems kind of over-powered for a platformer, often the compulsion I had was to just leap over everything en route to my destination rather than taking the scenic, more exploratory (and thus more rewarding) path, which is more than possible. Unboxing is tied to a health bar, the more you jump the lower your health. Health pickups and checkpoints are so plentiful though, there's really not much to dissuade you from just passing everything by if you are so inclined. 

This game is good, but I wonder if, were there more like it available now I would find it as palatable as I do.

The designs are very artsy and fun to decorate.  I think we just stood there for a good few long moments decorating the box each time.  That and crawling into every narrow space to find the tape. Very fun!  Thank you and keep up the good work.  Much appreciated. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197974613347', 'num_games_owned': 524, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 672, 'last_played': 1503347371}
review: This game gives me hope for the future of gaming. I think we all remember a time when games were just fun. No DLC, no microtransactions, you pay one price, you get a fun game, you play through it once or twice, and it stands on its own as a great single player exprience. That's what this is. There are some things that could be improved about this game, but the fact is that I couldn't keep from smiling while playing it. Collect-a-thon platformers are back, baby, and they're back with a vengeance!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002237289', 'num_games_owned': 1138, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1504371993}
review:
Thank you devs. Not just for bridging the gap before the release of Yooka-Laylee, but giving me the biggest grin on my face and taking me right back to my childhood!

Lately I've been feeling a little exhuasted by gaming in general, too many samey AAA games vying for my attention. I've still got Witcher 3 and Tomb Raider waiting for me to start but I'm lacking the energy to invest another 20-60 hours in a game right now.

Unbox has brought me right back. It's a total breath of fresh air.
