author: {'steamid': '76561198042013071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1603, 'last_played': 1478875592}
review:
Ich kann dieses Spiel klar empfehlen. Der Preis ist in jedem Fall angemessen und man hat viel Spa√ü damit. Es ist zwar Stellenweise sehr kindlich angehaucht und versucht stellenweise Zwanghaft witzig zu sein, aber dennoch hat man einiges an Spa√ü. Es ist kein Riesenspiel aber f√ºr den Spa√üfaktor auf jedenfall zu empfehlen. Im gro√üen und ganzen ein echt gutes Spiel. 
Bugs gab es nur sehr wenige und bis auf 2 haben mich davon auch keine gest√∂rt. Die beiden die ich als nerven empfunden habe, waren dass oft wenn ich in einer Mission eine andere Box an mich gebunden hatte, das meine Figur nicht mehr richtig gesprungen ist weil der andere Teil irgendwo h√§ngen geblieben war. Der andere Bug war in einer der Speedmissionen, wo der Wagen nicht gespawnt wurde oder manchmal der Respawn, genau da gesetzt wurde wo ich die Klippe runter gefallen bin. Aber beides nichts Weltbewegendes. Und ein Tipp, in der 2. Welt (Schnee) bei dem einen Rennen kann es passieren, dass wenn man zu schnell ist, das der Checkpoint nicht aktiviert wird (wo man durch eine "Box" springen muss).
Die Steuerung ist mit Tastatur und Maus extremst nervt√∂tent und nicht zu empfehlen da sie zu empfindlich ist und man keinen Sprung schafft und auch sonst viele Probleme hat. (Da die Hauptfigur eine Box ist, rollt sie auch wie eine was oft sehr frustrierend war).
Mit Kontroller hingegen ist es angenehm. Nicht perfekt aber gut genug um Spa√ü zu haben. Es gibt viele Eastereggs und viel Spa√ü in dem Spiel. Viele der Nebencharakt√§re blieben mir auch im Ged√§chtnis, da sie einfach so total bescheuert waren oder irgendwie besonders waren. Stellenweise kam auch das alte Super Mario N64 feeling auf. Nat√ºrlich ist es nicht zu vergleichen, aber dennoch √§hnlich. 
Frustrierende bzw. schwere Ecken gab es nicht viele, es war die meiste Zeit relativ einfach bzw. fair(mal von der Steuerung abgesehen) . Die einzige Mission wo ich mein Gamepad am liebsten gegen die Wand geworfen h√§tte war eine Mission auf der letzten Karte und eine andere auf der 1. Aber ich m√∂chte euch nicht spoilern. Grafisch hab ich nicht viel auszusetzen, es hat seinen eigenen Flair und hat Ihn gut durchgehalten. 
Ansonsten sind einige der freizuschaltenden Kost√ºme echt lustig und es ist am√ºsant was man mit seiner Kiste alles machen kann.
F√ºr Archievementj√§ger kann ich das Spiel auch empfehlen, ich habe viel Zeit vertr√∂delt und auch √∂fter einfach mal nur Dialoge gelesen, hab es aber 100% durch und es gab auch keine Archievements wo man ewig lange Spielen m√ºsste bzw. extrem schwere/hirntote Aufgaben erledigen muss. Auch gibt es keine Verpassbaren Archievements. (Ein Tipp: Die kleine Rote Kiste die wir im Tutorial kennen lernen, ist in jedem Missionsgebiet zu finden. Wenn am Ende noch Rollen oder Puzzleteile fehlen, sprecht Ihn an und er wird euch ein Bild von dem Platz zeigen wo diese sind. (Mehrmals anreden ist auch m√∂glich um das Bild aus verschiedenen Winkeln zu sehen)).
Die Story war nicht sonderlich tiefgr√ºndig, aber es ging ja eh in erster Linie nur um den Spa√ü und in dem Spiel steckt viel Liebe f√ºrs Detail. Aus diesem Grund kann ich es klar empfehlen.
Ich muss jedoch zugeben das ich den Multiplayermodus noch nicht ausprobiert habe und bisher auch nichts positives dr√ºber geh√∂rt habe. Hierf√ºr lest am besten eine andere Review.

TL:DR - Das Spiel macht Spa√ü, ist fesselnd, viel liebe f√ºrs Detail und auch einige Eastereggs (z.B. kann man auf der 3. Insel ein Bonfire aus Dark Souls finden) zu finden. Die Archievements sind alle relativ leicht und machbar. Aber wer ein schweres Spiel sucht und kein Gamepad hat bzw. viel Geduld f√ºr die Tastatursteuerung mit bringt sollte die Finger von dem Spiel lassen. Der Preis ist angemessen und wer wollte denn noch nicht ein sich selbst auslieferndes P√§ckchen sein. :)

Danke f√ºrs lesen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995667852', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1478840659}
review: A good platformer. Some of the physics of being a box aren't always the most pleasant, as occasionally you'll try to jump but not be on the ground, and the boss fights are more tasking than fun, but an enjoyable experience nevertheless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041590859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 994, 'last_played': 1478832657}
review:
This certainly is a great 3D platformer as based on the 90's classics. Good for a few hours of gameplay and easy enough to collect all achievements.

Singleplayer has an average story with some questions left unanswered, which hopefully could be tackled if some additional levels were added [spoiler]What ever happened to all the humans and to GPS? Will we get some DLC in space with weightless jumps?[/spoiler] Plenty of Unreal 4 mechanics used for gameplay, appear in many other unreal titles so not the most impressive such as driving etc. Would also have liked some more skills, plenty of buttons going spare on the controller that could have been mapped to, such as being able to carry and drop off items such as bombs to remote areas or collapsing down to a sheet of cardboard to slide through tiny cracks.

Haven't had a chance to play multiplayer yet but have seen videos. Looks fun and I appreciate the 4 way splitscreen, definitely a title to pull up during a gathering/party.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272125194', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1659482747}
review:
Unbox is a colorful platform adventure.
I would completely recommend this game, but only if you have friends to play it with. The story mode is okay, but the real fun is the multiplayer. It can get quite tedious, though, because the world is very large and there is many things to collect. It gets to a point where it hinders your fun to try and collect everything. I would wait for the game to go on sale, because most likely it is going to be sitting in your library with 4.6 hours. 

Overall okay game. Get it for you little sister and have a good time.

6.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198049863266', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 736, 'last_played': 1632445922}
review: If you loved the platformers of the N64 era such as Super Mario 64, Donkey Kong 64 and Banjo Kazooie then you need to play this game. Collection-fest platformers have become extremely rare in modern gaming, but with the release of Unbox (and the eventual release of Uke and Lele) perhaps we will start to see more indie teams looking to this genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198258395930', 'num_games_owned': 475, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1522190579}
review: Great game to zone out to. Upbeat soundtrack, collectathon gameplay and pretty visuals make for some good time. 21/29

author: {'steamid': '76561198000599137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1479924205}
review: If you liked console platformers in the 90s and 00s, buy this game. The gameplay and controls very tight and polished, the visuals are beautiful, and the world is fun and interesting. The world has a similar vibe as Mario Sunshine, which I love. The boxes are quite amusing and I've laughed out loud at many of the jokes. Honestly, the only part of this game that isn't super polished and amazing is the cutscenes, and they're not really that important anyway. The camera is a bit wonky of course, but that's just an inherent part of any 3D platformer. Overall the camera is still quite good and better than most classic games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035476645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 722, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 722, 'last_played': 1478372165}
review:
To make it short and sweet, yes I do recommend this game based on its merits alone in standing up as a short but sweet experience with an experience more compelling than you'd expect from literal cardboard boxes. 

Now with that, here are some pros and cons: 

Pros: 
-Quirky 'box' characters
-Heavily inspired by late 90's platformers with regards to gameplay and worlds
-Plenty of collectibles and costumes in game to try on
-Active Publisher/Developer that still constantly reachable online and releasing free updates 
-Charming humour (may make you groan or cringe but guaranteed to make you react) 
-Variety in quests, boss battles, and world design
-Hidden Eastern eggs and nods to other games/pop culture moments 
-Sound effects and music that keep the atmosphere alive with energy
-Multiplayer included! 

Cons: 
-No built-in steam shop support (not even for custom costumes)
-Game under 10 hours of gameplay unless going for 100% completion (currently at $17.99 steam at time of writing)
-Controls are frustrating (as to be expected by controlling a box, not a sphere) 
-Camera-work equally frustrating, especially when giving you 'hints' from Bounce
-Load times inbetween game start-up and world loading screens strangely long
-Lack of actual game walkthroughs/tips online to help if trying for true 100% collection goals 
-Tutorials/Help Tips can seem never-ending at times, as what at first will feel helpful and guiding through confusing parts (especially the initial tutorial) can devolve into repetitive information, especially when asking for locations of certain items or challenges

Overall it may seem like a game that can leave mixed impressions and I won't deny that it certainly will try your patience at certain times. However the game is built that way because it motivates you to go 100% collecting all the way if that's your cup of tea. Otherwise it doesn't mind if you focus instead on just the main story and that by itself is worth the game. Also much of the gripes I listed in cons you either get used to or are acceptable when viewed overall at a game that does a lot of things right and if you like a challenge with regards to modern platforming, is right up your alley than.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997232645', 'num_games_owned': 391, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1497655306}
review:
This is one game whose metascore I very much disagree with. Polished like the biggest jewel on the crown of a king, this quirky platformer generates a feeling I haven't felt for a long, long time. With surprisingly great controls, high mobility, very shiny graphics, and delightful music, Unbox coalesces all of its strengths into an experience that simultaneously feels grand and innocent. This is the kind of game of which I would have strong, fond memories, had it come out when I was a child.

I think those critics just don't get it, and are applying an inappropriate set of standards. You wouldn't evaluate the animation of a Disney movie with the same standards with which you would evaluate a painting from the Renaissance era, would you? No, you wouldn't. That would be stupid.

Ignore the metascore. This game is one to experience -- it's cute, ridiculous, satisfying, and surprisingly large.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979724838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 376, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1477918164}
review:
Unbox feels like a kid who's starstruck by their own parents. It thinks so highly of what they do and tries so hard to emulate them, and it's cute but ends up falling short because of a fundamental lack of understanding.

Right out of the gate the game holds you on a leash through a forced tutorial for just long enough to be aggravating, while dangling pickups here and there in your face but saying "oh no, little Billy, you can't get those just yet!" if you attempt to stray so much as 2 feet off the trodden path. Then, by the end of the tutorial, you are familiarized with your titular Unbox ability which allows you to take as many as 7 consecutive jumps at the cost of your health meter. It is how you will mobilize yourself through the rest of the game, scrounging for the obligatory collectibles and completing (re)quests in the form of instanced minigames. You can also stomp with B to hit buttons or defend yourself.

This never changes. This is the entire game.

It controls awkwardly, because of a semi-accurately simulated "rolling box" physics model for your movement, and jumping, unboxing, and pounding are mapped to RB, LB, and B respectively. The cast of characters is flat and insipid, with probably 90% of the population being literal clones of the oblivious, happy-go-lucky, incompetent, bad-pun-spewing stooge by name of Zippie and the remaining 10% being pretty much the same one-note caricature besides. Both the hub world and the first main level you go to have very similar, very repetitive caribbean-themed music with two-chord backing tracks and I never want to hear another steel drum in my life. The graphics are nice! I like how everything looks. But even all this aside, the game's primary stumbling block is that there's a blatantly straightforward and yet completely squandered opportunity for a good sense of progression.

Stamps are foisted as the most important pickup because they apparently unlock new worlds, so they got that much right (although I seem to have access to at least 3 worlds from the start anyway). There are occasionally special fragments tucked away in really well-hidden places that are kind of fun to dig for. But simultaneously the most prominent and pointless pickup is golden tape; it is the bananas / musical notes of Unbox, with a whopping [i]200[/i] to collect on every single level, and yet it serves [i]no point whatsoever[/i]. Perhaps it unlocks an extra cosmetic or something, but if the developers were riding on cosmetics as a main driving force of the gameplay then I'm not sure who they were making this for.

You start the first world with all of your abilities. You don't unlock extra jumps. You don't unlock rounded edges to make movement easier. The only things you unlock in this game are cosmetics and doors. There [i]could have been[/i] a much more intriguing system in place here, perhaps requiring you to gradually unlock progressive extra jumps per level, meaning you'd have to make do with the lower areas at first or come up with cheesy ways of exploiting physics to sequence break. Maybe your progress in the separate worlds would dictate how much of the hub world you could access. But when everything's set in stone from the start, the entire point of the collectathon genre has swooped by overhead. It's like if you started Saints Row 4 with all your upgrades and superpowers at their full cap; yeah, you [i]could[/i] go around and collect hundreds of glowy pickups, but why would you want to?

author: {'steamid': '76561198067923465', 'num_games_owned': 962, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1479340926}
review:
Sous ses allures de grand jeu mignon et color√© se cache en r√©alit√© une fable sociale aux enjeux sombres et..

Unbox est un jeu de plate-forme qui rend hommage aux grands du genre en adoptant une structure √† la Jak & Daxter (environnements semi-ouverts dans lesquels on se balade librement pour r√©colter des trucs) ou √† la Mario 64 (avec un hub central, Other Base, comprenez la r√©f√©rence, lol, rires, on se tape les cuisses). On joue une bo√Æte dans un monde rempli de bo√Ætes qui doit combattre les m√©chants punks altermondialistes anticapitalistes etc en se baladant dans des environnements... Vraiment beaux pour le coup. La grosse force d'Unbox je pense c'est √ßa, l'ambiance est color√©e, joyeuse, y'a du monde, la musique est bien, on ne s'ennuie pas malgr√© l'action qui pent sembler un poil r√©p√©t√©tive. Y'a de l'humour, la bande-son est vraiment sympa, bref c'est un jeu qui vous arrachera quelques sourires pour vous faire oublier √† quel point votre vie est triste et morose. Franchement de base il peut para√Ætre un peu cher mais il vaut le coup pour ceux qui aimeraient revivre l'univers des plateformers 3D d'il y a dix ans ! (bon les graphismes sont actuels, pas de craintes √† ce niveau l√†).

author: {'steamid': '76561197965185195', 'num_games_owned': 454, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1477729195}
review:
Super Mario World type mechanics (with a Lego sense of humor?) with an RNG movement factor (on account of being cube shaped with all the rolling inaccuracy you come to expect).   
Worth noting that I had an easier time controlling with a mouse and keyboard than controller.  
The game has racing, shooting challenge elements.
Chasing collectibles for 100% is frustrating at best when you `just barely miss` because of the cube movement.
Meanwhile, the game also has a multi-player deathmatch mode shoehorned into it as well (Relive the N64 console hype?)

Having grown up with titles like Mario, BanjoKazooie, Conkers, DiddyKongRacing...  This game really does try to fit into that niche with the whole cardboard box theme, but at the end of the day the movement frustrations of the box wobbling about just aren't endearing enough to suffer through for an entire 3d platforming adventure - its bad enough to play a round a mini golf with a cube as is!
I'm pretty sure if the movement was clean, I probably would have had a little more patience for the game.   Maybe a marble madness theme?  XD

When I play a platformer, I expect my character to move the way I tell it - otherwise there's just a very artificial slowdown to the entire game which doesn't feel good at all.   I would never recommend this game as anything more than a drunken penalty game, except maybe as to use this game as a pre-Christmas gift for a kid that was being a brat about not being allowed to open gifts early?  XD   Toss this to them instead and watch the look on their face as they play it for the first hour or so?   Then tell them they can open one gift for each level they 100% complete?

author: {'steamid': '76561198050715681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1477685908}
review: It fits very well into that late 90's, early 2000's 3D platformer asthetic (which it aims for). Even beyond the nostalgia, the mechanics are great, and once you get past the initial awkwardness of rolling around, controls are very tight and responsive. Definitely advise playing with a controller. Great great fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984305602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1462, 'last_played': 1615408985}
review:
I have to say that Unbox is exactly as advertised and a little more; a beautiful throwback to the N64-era 3D platformers. Down to nearly every detail, it will remind you of those wonderful days of gaming.

The physics are far superior to anything that could have been offered in the late 90's, as are the graphics (but without seeming too flashy). They retain the cartoon, polygon appearance we all love, and the spirit of those games is upheld even in the characters "speaking"

I only really have one complaint about this game, and it pains me to admit it, but it has made me start to lose interest just a tad. In the 3D platformers (actually all platformers, back to the NES), there were lots of short levels where you could feel a sense of accomplishment, many times, over a few hours. This game doesn't really do that for me.

I enjoy open-world games as much as anyone else, but in many other successful games there's still incremental payoffs that occur fairly frequently ie. deeply interesting story and accomplishments or brief challenges with frequent minor rewards along the way. I did not get that with this game.

I would play another game in this style, from the same dev's, again for sure. But I would really hope for twice the levels/worlds and 2/3's the collectibles per level. At that point it would be absolutely equal to Banjo-Kazooie or Mario 64, or all the other fantastic games this emulates. Hands down.

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198076842069', 'num_games_owned': 1154, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1483375782}
review:
What is Unbox?
https://youtu.be/LdmNT1Y9HOA
Unbox is a throwback to 90s platformers with obvious inspiration being taken from games such as Glover, Conker and Banjo and Kazooie on the Nintendo 64. 

You play as Newbie, a box. I take it you understand the title of the game now.

Newbie was created by the Global Postal Service, GPS for short, with the sole aim of saving the floundering company. Newbie was created not only is a sentient  box, but also a self-delivering box, which would not only save the company money, but save it from bankruptcy.

Controls:
Well, you're a box, you move how a box would, turning is delicate, the controls can be quite jagged and can be at times, tough to control. I found that when I was moving faster I was definitely struggling more, but if you pace your movement and try to aim your jumps and movement it becomes more fluid.

There are a number of moves which Newbie has in his arsenal including slam, unbox, and jump.

While movement is tough at the start, it gets easier the more you play it, don't let the initial frustration throw you and spoil the experience for you. 

Soundtrack:
The game sounds like Banjo and Kazooie, the NPCs all respond with similar meeps and merps, as well as having similar interactions with the player. These small details help the player to embrace the world and the retro vision the developers had. Either that or they were too cheap to pay for voice actors, or they weren't sure what a box would sound like.

The soundtrack is alright, a bit repetitive at times, but it fits each world well. If you're a collection enthusiast it could definitely grate on you, and considering the game is somewhat of a collectathon I could definitely see that happening to some players.

In Conclusion:
Unbox is a very fun game which is suitable for a lot of people, of many ages, it has an expansive and colorful environment and quality gameplay to boot, while being not too difficult, it's also not too easy and definitely has replay value. Would I recommend it? Definitely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044067612', 'num_games_owned': 12185, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1475272616}
review:
Unbox is a very charming N64-style collect-a-thon platformer.

In Unbox you control a box(duh), that can move, jump and unbox(essentially a extra jump). You have to collect a certain ammount of items in the levels to proceed to the boss fight and then to the next level.

Which levels is quite big and detailed world, being almost a open-world-lite per level. You have several quests and activities, like rescuing other boxes,  races, challenges, and even combat against the "bad boxes" It offers good variety if you just want to progress, although it might get a bit too saturated if you aim for 100% every level (but then again that's true for most of the games in the genre)

Made in Unreal Engine 4, it does look pretty good, even more so coupled with the charming artstyle. The worlds are full of detail and are consistent throughout. It's very pleasing to the eye. The worlds are also pretty different from one another which keeps the experience fresh (a oil rig, a tropical island, snow mountains and a jungle with ancient ruins).

Soundwise, it's quite good. There's lot of sound effects and details that help the world come alive, and the banter from NPCs is reminiscent of stuff like Banjo and others. The soundtrack is alright and it fits each world well, but it is a bit flawed in there's little variety in it and each theme can be repetitive in itself, so while well composed those themes might be grating while trying to 100% a level.

As for controls: it handles exactly how you'd think a box would handle. As it is a box and it has corners, you will get the expected behaviour from it which will make it a bit erratic compared to what you would expect from other games with characters that have a more "smooth" appearance and gameplay. It takes a little bit to adjust(20-30 minutes), but when it does, it becomes natural and it handles quite well. The unbox mechanics, which consists in essentially adding a extra jump(up to 6 max). It makes it a game very fun to speedrun, coupled with the momentum physics that can make you go roll at very high speeds. I was worried it would trivialize the game too much, but after playing it for a quite a bit I don't think it does. Making big skips and jumps still requires skill and for you to have proper control of the character.

The boss sections aren't bad, but they might be too simple for their own good. It doesn't feel like you take full of advantage of what you learned from the levels and that's a shame. It would be really good if they added more platforming on those sections.


All in all, it is one of my favorite platformer games in 2016, with a few flaws, but I heartily recommend it at the current price(it's also 12$ on the new Humble Bundle). I'd love to see a bigger sequel in the future, this could become really special with the right budget.

review:
So, I got this game yesterday, and I was so excited to play it, and then it crashed during the loading of The Other Base. It is a message that keeps on popping up there everytime I get to the loading screen. It says: "Windows failed to allocate video memory. Try closing background applications, play at lower resolution-" and something else. I try this and it still doesn't work. Do I need to get a certain thing to run this game, or will it just not work?

(P.S. I recommend this because I don't know if it is just my computer. Hoping to get a new one soon. Great job with the game, Unbox!)
developer_response: Hi Victor, we're sorry to hear you're having issues with Unbox, have you checked to see if your PC meets the minimum specification on the Unbox product page?

review: If you like games like Banjo-Kazooie you owe it to this developer to at least check out the demo. It's less expansive than the Rare games, but at only 15.99 bucks this is a great snack while we wait for Yooka-Laylee. It's fun to play, there's a lot of silly humour and references (I really liked the BioShock one) and the world is awesome. Hoping to see more games in this franchise (maybe with added abilities next time?).

author: {'steamid': '76561198025468353', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1475191052}
review:
Unbox has quickly and mercilessly shattered all of my expectations to become one of my favorite games of 2016.  Unbox is the harbinger of the Rare-vival.  Many of us feel the warm nostalgies for our classic collectathons such as Banjo-Kazooie and Donkey Kong 64 and we crave something new in this genre.  But it's not the genre that we really miss.  It's that wonderful personality that those games had.  That goofy sense of humor, that hilarious cartoon approach to characters that made us feel like we'd jumped into a saturday morning cartoon.  That's what Unbox nails.  That's why you should play this game.  Unbox is fun, the mechanics are great, the graphics look good, the music is a delight but all of that is secondary to the amazing personality that this game brings to the table.  I didn't get this game for free, I'm not biased, I'm just a huge advocator of people having fun and this game is pure joy in a box.

Here's a video review for those of you who need to see my wonderful face to be convinced of what I just told you:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p9Hu6SAZfPY

author: {'steamid': '76561198029806555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1043, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1039, 'last_played': 1568215005}

review: Having to live in the real world now and playing games I feel like I rush them and not look around and enjoy them as much as I used to.  Unbox takes me back to a time when I just knew every time a game loaded up that it would be enjoyable.  It's funny, cute, great graphics and a brilliant concept.  Love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972215659', 'num_games_owned': 491, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1491064897}
review:
Great Level Design so far and wonderfully amusing set dressing and characters!

Only really rough spot in the main design is the physics based character movement, but I understand that is needed for the game concept. It is still functional but you can often end up careening off a cliff when things get chaotic.

Only bug I found so far is that the background music sometimes cuts out, which is a shame since it is so good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984649158', 'num_games_owned': 674, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1474046904}
review:
[h1]A modern take on classic 90's platformers[/h1]

If, like me, you grew up playing classic 90's platformers such as Spyro the Dragon and Banjo Kazooie, Unbox is the game for you. Placing you in the role of a sentient cardboard box (because, why not) Unbox lets you fling yourself freely around several large environments, tasking you with collecting a variety of objects in order to progress to the next level. It looks great, it controls great, it's just great in general. Unbox. It's worth both your time and hard earned cash.

If you want to know more of my thoughts, feel free to watch a more in-depth review over on my YouTube channel:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u_dFxhEdfh0

author: {'steamid': '76561198277025532', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1608885374}

author: {'steamid': '76561197991921123', 'num_games_owned': 3825, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1479124359}
review: I have been having a blast with Unbox so far. It is very reminiscent of games like Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine and other collection/platformer games. The controls are really good and responsive making even the toughest platforming puzzles easy. The use of Unreal engine 4 make this game easily one of the best looking of the genre. The open world aspect of the game makes it very casual and allows you to explore and do the tasks available at your leisure. The environments are really as big and expansive as the store screenshots show. The game runs great and I have had no issues at all. A really great game and I 100% recommended it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198050670989', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1473466981}
review:
This game has a lot of heart it really does. I love the box rolling mechanic, I think it's incredibly fun.
Here are a couple of the main reasons why I don't reccomend this game despite the game's charm and appeal.

First, right off the bat, the game has long unskipable cutscenes which wouldnt be a problem if it's not for what comes next in the list.

Second, the map design in the game is great and a lot of fun. The problem is there is this mechanic in the game called UNBOX which essentially uses a life to launch you great distances. which ends up turning this map that, at the start of the game seemed overwhelmingly large. To a much smaller map due to your increase in speed and mobility. It turned all the obstacles into non-problems. This was killer for me. and what made it worse was:

Third: You unlock all your abilities at the start of the game. This is what turned me off of the game. This game has a lot of potential without the UNBOX abliity The tutorial levels where you can't use it are really fun. They should have waited till later in the game to give it to you. You can really see the developers struggle to make interesting missions with this ability simply due to how overpowered it is.

Fourth: The missions in this game struggle to keep the game interesting. I hate to say it, but they really do. This is for a couple reasons. One, the story itself can't really figure out it's main purpose so they really just drop you in and say "have fun" with no real reason why you need to do these missions. Plus most of the missions are completely inconsistent in difficulty and time to complete. This game has collectables similar to banjo-kazooie as you are probably aware. But the main "stamp" collectable is what gets you essentially to the next level. But one mission can take you less then a minute to complete saying "go here". And others that are whole races which you need to get 3 gold metals to get one stamp. I think this just goes back to the developers trying to accomadate for the UNBOX launch.

Fifth and Finally: The story. The reason this is last is because in these collectathon games story is ususally of minimal importance. BUT! This story is particularly confusing. Lets get some of the minor gripes right off the bat. Other characters have somewhat inconsistant personalities but tend to stay true to their "Archetype". The major problem I have with the story is the fact that the developers never actually figured out a driving force. You start the game as "The box that will save the shipping company" which is a fantastic premise. Then they go on to the first main "open world" island. And tell you "oh forget about it, go and have fun doing our missions". It just never feels like you are making any progress despite beating the boss, and going through levels.

tl;dr
Game has fun mechanics and a fun story and interesting level design, but is dwarfed by game breaking powerups that should have been locked till the end of the game, a story which loses purpose within the first 20 minutes of playing, and challenges which fail to remain interesting for long periods of play.

The developers show a lot of potential in this game, and I can't wait to see what they come up with next.  Given a chance to learn from their mistakes with this game. Hopefully the next one is fantastic.

EDIT:

I've been informed by Cancer's Spooky Cousin* that you can now skip cutscenes

*I know

author: {'steamid': '76561197987589515', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1473649371}
review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1]

     First off, I'd like to say that I saw this announced a while back and have been pretty stoked about it since. However, I was kind of disappointed when I finally got my hands on it a couple days ago. Furthermore, I only have two hours on record so there may be some later content that I did not access and therefore cannot know that it might relate to the things that I am going to write about below. Also, I guess I'll add a TL;DR at the bottom.

____________________________________________________________

[h1] Collectibles [/h1]

     For the first half-hour or so, I found myself lost in the game's charm. It was fun rolling around as a little mustachio'd box with all my other sentient box friends but it grew kind of dull after a while.
     After the tutorial was over, I went on to just start collecting things because that's what you do in this kind of game. Just to explain this a little further there are three different kinds of collectibles: Gold Tape (the plentiful, 'coin-style' one), Trapped Zippies (the bonus 'free your friends!' one), and Stamps (the main 'star-type' one). Those three things are what you'll find around the world of 'Unbox.' Now, here is what I think could be improved on:

     I feel like there should be maybe one or two more types of collectibles. Having two hundred rolls of Gold Tape strewn about each world comes off as a little lazy, especially considering these are the types of items that tend to be collected while on the way from one objective to another. While there are plenty on the roads and paths, a lot of them are also quite hidden so the player must search high and low for them all which, normally, wouldn't be so bad but there are just way too many. I think changing the amount from two hundred to one hundred and then adding a new collectible would be a better option.

[h1] Difficulty and General Gameplay [/h1]

     Next, I'd like to talk about the difficulty and other things related. The game feels far too easy and I understand it's supposed to be a casual collect-a-thon (and that's okay, I love games like that) but 'Unbox' lacks something that keeps me engaged. I breezed through whatever challenges were in my way and the only difficulties I had were from the wonkiness of trying to roll around as a cube-shaped object. While I understand that is the point of the game, I'd like to say that it's too much here. A game can be wonky and still feel right to the player (think Katamari here or even Starwhal if you've ever played it) but this game does not do that for me. Instead, I would find myself frustrated that I failed missions or missed an item due to a messed up jump because my box was laying at an awkward angle or something like that. I think the gameplay would greatly benefit from something that could add a level of fluidity or smoothness such as slightly rounded collisions or much less rough terrain. In short, the only challenging part of this game is its handling and not in a fun way.

[h1] Writing, Story, and Development [/h1]

     Continuing on, I'd like to mention the less important aspects of the game such as writing and whatnot. I say, "less important" because I know that these things weren't the developers' primary focus here, but since this is a review, they're worth mentioning.

     To put it bluntly, the story is not good (spoilers ahead). It's like this: GPS (Global Postal Service) is going out of business because they can't stop losing people's stuff. As a last ditch effort, they started manufacturing sentient, self-delivering boxes. However, this didn't entirely work and they were still in trouble. So, as a last-last ditch effort, they designed a totally new and improved box that was supposed to be much better than all the others (that box is the player). Then everyone keeps saying that you're the only one who can save GPS and that's pretty much it. ...or is it?

     Almost immediately, a good 'ol 'mystery character with an ambiguous moral alignment' arc is thrown in. There is no build-up, there is no point, there is only 'Mystery Box.' He also very quickly reveals that the G in GPS doesn't stand for 'Global,' but in fact 'Galactic' so this also has something to do with aliens and/or space or something. It just feels like the developers didn't really know what they wanted to do with their own game. Also, they do this thing when you continue your game or travel to a different world that automatically tries to replay the most recent story-related cutscene and I don't like or understand that at all.

     That being said, I do really like the world that 'Unbox' is set in. The idea of sentient delivery boxes that just want to bring things to people is cute and fun. There's also 'Mop,' a box that used to deliver mops until marketing research decided that wasn't really selling. He's sad and that makes me sad because all he wants to do is deliver mops. But anyway, the game is beautiful, the environments are great, and I really love the concept. I just really don't love the writing. In addition to that, the villains, otherwise known as the 'Wild Cards,' are super annoying. I don't mean they're annoying as characters, they're annoying in-game. The player will occassionally come across these guys whilst in the middle of going somewhere or doing something and they don't add anything to the gameplay at all. They just knock you around and they're a nuisance. But I guess that belongs in the gameplay section? I'm too lazy to move it and it's a kind of acceptable segue into the fact that I also hate Bounce. This character is also incredibly annoying because he/she/it never stops giving me useless hints from the tutorial. Please add a 'Turn off Bounce' option for everyone else to enjoy.

[h1] Bugs [/h1]

     Finally, I'd like to address bugs. At the time of this review, 'Unbox' is at v1.02 and still contains a number of bugs. This is pretty okay due to the game being brand new, but it's a necessary thing to mention in a review.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

     To conclude, 'Unbox' is a fun game in its own right. However, it falls short of what one might consider to be a polished game and its only saving grace is the creativity of the concept and world. There are just too many smaller issues to ignore, which is why I cannot recommend this to others.

     [b] TL;DR: [/b] The game is neat but it falls short in fluidity and, to some extent, quality of content. The story is also bad but the overall conceptual part is pretty cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984078553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1473701031}
review:
This is something I didn't know I wanted so bad. This just takes you back to playing games like Spyro, Gek, TY, and Croc.

You jump around massive game levels as a box who can Unbox, into a smaller box, and doing so will give you a "double jump" which you can do up to 6 times. While it can be sometimes awkward as a box to roll around, the platforming controls in the game are extremely tight and well thought out. It's a pleasure to play.

I've seen 3 of the games levels which are huge, and they all look beautiful. I highly recommend if you're not sure about the game to at least play through to the 2nd level, not including the hub, as moving around in that level is such a blast as you slide along in the ice.

A small complaint if I had one was about the music in the game (at least on the 1st main level) almost driving me insane. The second levels music sounds a lot less prominent and therefore less annoying though. 

This is game you should definitely pick back if you want to chill and do a bit of exploring / platforming, while collecting a whole bunch of stuff.

the only thing i dont like in this game is the pop in which isnt to bad and you get use to it pretty quick

author: {'steamid': '76561197996715488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 308, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 513, 'last_played': 1473623837}
review:
Exploration Collectable Platformer
Fun little game that didn't really do anything that hasn't been done before but does what it needed to right.

Pros:
Large open world, no invisible walls
World is flavorful, not lifeless. Most open worlds are just hills and trees and roads with points of interests here and there. In Unbox everything and everwhere feels designed, no filler
Movement is simple and unirritating, the devs give you a sextuple jump so you can go where you want to go no hassle
Every collectable you failed to find? There's an NPC that will show you where it is so you have a chance of finding it in this huge environment

Cons:
Story? Meh.
Dialogue? Meh.
Music? Meh.

There's a lot to see in Unbox, and you don't need to collect everything. But if you don't want to do that then there's nothing really else for you.

Completion: 10.5 hours for a 100% run. I imagine about 6-7 if you don't care about collectables at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999839135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 1505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1137, 'last_played': 1611583249}
review: Unbox is an amazing throwback to classic collectathon 3D platoformers. Its a very light hearted world filled with fun characters with silly dialogue. Using the power of Unreal, the developers created some huge open world levels to explore. With lots of collectibles fun physics, great level design, and some unique mechanics, Unbox is a must have for fans of the genre. GG!

author: {'steamid': '76561198040884867', 'num_games_owned': 2434, 'num_reviews': 901, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1473496551}
review:
As far as indie 90's style 3D platformers go, I think the indie scene has some pretty weak sauce. [i]FREEZEme[/i] had a lot of heart, but was completely amateur-hour with the rough edges. [b][i]Unbox[/i] looks great, has a truly novel (and fun!) mechanic, and knows what its audience wants as far as the collection aspect.[/b] This title is quite polished too, and has tons of content.

[i]Essentially, there is a series of islands loaded with collectables, storyline, and lots to do.[/i] The main mechanic is that you can 'unbox' six times (it would be equivelant to having a 'double' jump, only six times). You replenish the boxes, or 'jumps' by collecting powerups which are in abundance and scattered all about. You collect gold tape icons, stamps, and save characters. The islands are huge, IMO. You can change skins, hats, and more. 

[b]The only negative side to this title is performance.[/b] I run VR games without a hitch, and this game makes my computer work more than those do. Don't get me wrong - I run it smoothly with no issues, but for whatever reason it makes the computer sweat. The graphics are beautiful, though. The loading times are hella long, as well.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Great 3D platformer throwback to all those great 90's titles
+Truly awesome 'unboxing' mechanic that really makes it standout
+Tons of collection and content
+It looks beautiful
+Controller support is great, and IMO, necessary to really enjoy this to the fullest
+Cute universe and characters

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Probably need a beefy machine to play at high graphics

[b]If you are a fan of the genre, get it.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198141916528', 'num_games_owned': 588, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1622693798}
review:
It's a great collectathon, but there are some missed opportunities, and at parts it feels like it was rushed. I'mma write some things that really sticked out.

- The Unbox Ability feels like it was added on a whim, the map is even build to be able to 
  traverse without it, honestly would've been more fun If you unlocked it at the end of the 
  game.There's also a vehicle license in the world but we "somehow" have it already 
  unlocked. also would've been fun if we unlocked it after the 1st boss fight.

- The Golden Tape is annoying to get at times, they should've enabled the sound it makes 
  before you've collected over a 100 (I think). Then it would've been easier to find and you 
  wouldn't need to look around aimlessly to hear a sound, or ask Bounce for a tip. (Also 
  stamps and Golden tapes make the same sound.)

- Missions repeat with different characters, could've been more diverse, honestly there 
  should've been more Characters in general as well, probably just some minor that appear 
  only in 1 world.

- There isn't a forklift centered mission.

- Bugs that I encountered that "apparently" haven't been fixed since launch: 
By going into the box the only "puzzle" stamp is located in your game freezes permanently (Alt+ F4).
If you ride the sled and somehow flip yourself backwards while sliding, the game should crash.
 
+ But something that I have to award is that the ice pathing in Parcel Peaks is incredibly fun 
   to use, so are the cars.

I'd say it's worth half the original price (works with my game time).
(I'd probably leave this game a positive review If I had had some support when I asked for it.)
P.S. Steam add an option that's between positive and negative please.

What a silly little game.  The page said it was like Mario 64 and Ratchet and Clank.  To me that covers a lot of territory... but it definitely covers this. author: {'steamid': '76561198058532134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1483490656}
review:
I had to purchase this game on launch and give it a shot. I have to say, I think this game is excellent. I'll start out with describing play style, then talk about the positives and negatives.

Obviously, this is a platformer game bringing back the days of Banjo Kazooie, Spyro and Crash Bandicoot. In regards to world and feel, it seems that Unbox hits it right on the head. I felt like I jumped right into a platformer world which made me happy. If was to compare the movement to the likes of 2D Nintendo games, I feel like it would compare more to a faster Mario play style than say a slower Donkey Kong Country style. You do have a lot of control over the boxes movement and it feels pretty easy to get used to.

On the positive side, well, this game is just really positive. The world is bright and fun, the interactions are light hearted, and the game sucked me in almost immediately. I was compeelled to start obsessing about finding gold tape because that's how I typically play these things. The box was fun to control, and yet surprisingly challenging. I thought the number of jumps you get would make it a bit easy but quickly found out how difficult it can get, but not in a super frustrating way. The game is definitely fun and I can't wait to try out some local co-op on the PC with friends!

My negatives are minor at best but I'll point them out. First, there are some reports of bugs but I only ran into one. I tried max view distance (depth?) which lets you see more of the world on your screen. Max is bugged for my setup and all I had was a strange fuzzy tunnel on the screen. Anything less than max worked fine though and I quickly settled back to the 90 default so I could see up close better. Second, someone already mentioned this but I felt like reiterating it. You can tell that this game was made on Unity. The boxes look great, but some of the world objects look a bit rigid for the rest of the world. I'm sure it's because Unbox doesn't have the art budget other titles have, but it isn't something that bothers me while playing.

Overall, this is a great game to sit back, relax, and enjoy the afternoon with. These are the games I love to play when I just need to de-stress! I'm really looking forward to Yooka-Laylee when it comes out, but we have a little ways to go before it releases. With the current 20% off promo, I feel like this game is a steal and you should definitely get it before the 12th! Support the platformers!!!

System: FX-8350 @ 4.6, 16 GB of RAM, 2 x R9 290 in Crossfire, SSD, Windows 10 64 bit, Monitor with FreeSync enabled. (Yeah, definitely expected more bugs than I got with my setup. Pleasantly surprised!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198085808714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1548544033}
review:
If you're a fan of the classic Rare/N64 3d platformers then I think you will have a blast with this game. They nailed the tone/feeling/gameplay of the era but in their own colourful inventive world of sentient self delivering boxes.

The gameplay mainly consists of free roming around the different worlds doing challenges for a cast of different Box characters scattered around the worlds. If successful you will receive a stamp form them. There is 20 stamps to collect in each world and 200 gold tapes scattered everywhere. The gold tapes are everywhere from just around on the floor to in some really hard to reach places (eg. On top of a really tall tower). There is also 10 caged box NPC's that need freeing in each map aswell as a Boss to beat. You can't face the boss until you have collected enough stamps to do so.

That's where the games one main mechanic comes into play, to move around the wolrds you can do a normal jump but you can "Unbox" while in the air to perform a double jump if you will. The great thing is that you can do it up to 6 times to get some serious air, you'll be flying thru the sky trying to land in some very hard to reach places coz you can see that shining golden tape just waiting to be collected.

You can only "Unbox" once for each Health box you have (up to 6). These Health boxes are in abundant supply tho so you rarely find you can't use the ability. There is also checkpoints scattered  around that when used will fill your health boxes up aswell as count as your next spawn point incase you die.

That brings me to explain that there is no real dying in this game. You will see tho that you can't hit the water more than once without "dying" which sends you back to the last checkpoint you visited with no consequences. You migh find that some collectables are so far out that you won't have enough Health boxes to get back to land, you can hold down a button/key and it will respawn back at the last checkpoint. You might get crushed by stompers and other hazards around the worlds but again all it will do is respawn you at last checkpoint.

So as i'm sure you can tell this game isn't supposed to be anything more than it is. A casual kid friendly collectathon game which has been a joy to play. You definetly see the Banjo-Kazooie influence all over this game down to the text boxes, the noises the NPC's make when talking and just the general gameplay similarities. I'd say this game is a lot easier than Banjo-Kazooie but I have only just unlocked the 2nd of 3 worlds from what I can tell (correct me if i'm wrong), so I don't know if the difficulty ramps up but I can't imagine it.

You have a main Hub world which also has stuff to collect in and which gives you access to the Worlds thru doors in different areas of the Hub. The worlds look huge and is really fleshed out into what theme it is supposed to be. The first one being a tropical island them and the only other world I have seen yet is a snow themed one complete with slippery snow. Can't wait to see what the next theme will be.

I found myself amazed at just how well it all works maybe being used to so many broken releases nowadays, it was such a nice suprise to play this and it just oozes Nintendo like quality control. I haven't encounterd a single bug/glitch while playing with a solid 60fps. Seriously if you like these type of games you will have a blast. 

There is even local 4 player races and battles which I haven't tried yet so won't comment on it.

Higly recommended if you like the games which it is inspired by. However if you like your games challenging, you probably won't find satisfaction here so probably give it a miss. The only real time you might notice a difficulty spike is when you are doing challenges for stamps as some of these are on time limits, which means you might fail a couple of times but they're still easy enough to get thru.

 If you do wanna just sit back and and enjoy a well made original nod to the golden era of the N64 then pick this up you won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026559886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1485907379}

author: {'steamid': '76561198020087176', 'num_games_owned': 905, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1473474151}
review:
Unbox ‚Äì Saltos y Nostalgia

Unbox, un juego de plataformeo lleno de colores, diversidad de locaciones, muchos personajes y f√≠sicas divertidas. El equipo desarrollador Prospect Games ve su obra inspirada en juegos como Banjo-Kazooie, donde la nostalgia les ayud√≥ a llevar a cabo este juego que pueden disfrutar desde ni√±os hasta los mas grandes en casa. Tuvimos una entrevista con sus creadores, la cual esta al final del articulo.

https://youtu.be/Xstrq25E074

Unbox nos cuenta la historia de una compa√±√≠a encargada de hacer env√≠os de correspondencia, la cual en su af√°n de no caer en la desgracia de la bancarrota decide empezar a crear cajas que se auto entregan a sus debidos destinos, ahorrando tiempo y dinero. Nosotros entramos en acci√≥n cuando se crea la ultima de las cajas, con la mejor tecnolog√≠a, si nombre es Newbie y sera la encargada se cumplir una serie de retos y misiones con tal de salvar la compa√±√≠a.

Enfocado en una experiencia de un jugador, con plataformeo como su experiencia jugable principal, Unbox nos propone salvar a GPS (Global Postal Service) de un inminente cierre de operaciones, para esto deberemos realizar muchas actividades, como recoger estampillas, las cuales se nos ser√°n otorgadas por medio de la realizaci√≥n de eventos o misiones que nos encomendaran los NPC‚Äôs del juego, que de paso cada uno tiene sus peculiaridades y actitudes, algunos con personalidades muy chistosas y alguno que otro muy gru√±√≥n.


Entre las actividades que deberemos realizar para ganar estampillas, est√°n acabar con los secuaces de Boss Wild , nuestro n√©mesis en el juego, en una de las misiones, nos dan dos minutos para acabar con 20 de los pillos que trabajan para Boss Wild, si lo logramos, ganaremos una estampilla. Otra de las misiones consist√≠a en ir a dejar una carta a uno de los NPC‚Äôs en cinco minutos, mientras evit√°bamos ser atacados por los ya mencionados secuaces, intentar evitar los enemigos, no caer al agua, evitar cajas con TNT y buscar la manera mas corta de llegar a destino a la misma vez, se vuelve un desaf√≠o divertido, otro enemigo son los Wildcards.

Pero quien es Boss Wild? De primera entrada el porque de su enojo es un misterio, conforme vamos avanzando nos vamos dando cuenta quien es y porqu√© esta tan enojado con la GPS. Ademas de los distintos personajes, podemos encontrar la sastrer√≠a, donde podemos cambiar el look de Newbie, dandole distintos colores, ponerle sombreros, agregarle detalles como bigotes, anteojos, entre otros, con hasta 40,000 posibilidades diferentes en cuanto a maneras de vestirle o cambiarle el ‚Äòlook‚Äò.

Lo mas llamativo de Unbox son sus distintos escenarios, todos super coloridos y bien detallados, el uso de Unreal Engine 4 fue sin duda un acierto. Podemos encontrar zonas nevadas donde podremos incluso esquiar, un pueblo donde viven las cajitas lleno de color, muy vivo, y super agradable a la vista, aqu√≠ es donde los ni√±os encontraran lo bonito de Unbox. Hay una jungla que nos traer√° recuerdos de Donkey Kong.


El juego tambi√©n viene con un modo multijugador para modo local, donde podemos juntarnos con otros 3 amigos y jugar distintos minijuegos muy divertidos. El audio del juego a√±ade una excelente banda sonora, con m√∫sica que va muy acorde a las √°reas en las que estemos jugando, uno que otro peque√±o problema al inicio del juego con respecto a las ‚Äòvoces‚Äò de los NPC‚Äôs en la introducci√≥n del juego es lo √∫nico que pudimos percibir.

En resumen, Unbox es una excelente propuesta jugable para los que gustan de los juegos plataformeros, entornos coloridos que nos traer√°n recuerdos de Mario 64 con saltos, rompecabezas y carreras contra reloj, a parte de este analisis, hablamos con el Director General en Prospect Games, Andrew Benninson, abajo la entrevista.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129479370', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1478451472}
review:
So I've been waiting about a year for this game and man was it worth the wait. There's not really much here in the way of a story but you get to play as a box. How many other games can you say that about? 
Feels and controls beautifully. Fast gameplay and no punishment. Completely casual but that doesn't mean there's no fun here.
To be completely fair there's not actually that much to it. It's basically an open world game with ni main missions. Just the side missions, but with a game like this with this much charm amd general joy just rolling around you don't mind.
I could spend hours in this game just rolling around and unboxing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014685360', 'num_games_owned': 539, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1483314321}
review:
OK! Anyone looking at this game and looking at the massive, and positive score it's getting and thinking of buying it, well three words! Go and buy it!
It's a refreshing fun game that does not take it self serious.

As a lot of reviewers have said already, it's like playing a Nintendo game back in the 90s.
Full of charm and humour and you get that feel of super Mario world 3D or one of the great Rare game.

The developers have put this on steam at a cheaper price upon early launch, but to be honest the full price is very very cheap for a really fun 3D / adventure game with platforming elements and other great ideal's thrown in to this awsome game.

It real feels like it should be on a console, but we have this style of game on PC!.
It's got so much stuff to do in it like shooting targets, quests for other little box buddies you meet along the way and even racing sections to.
Also you have baddie's to fight and the normal Boss sort of fights to.
And from the mini games you do as well, it well sort of feels a little like Mario party to!.

There is so much to say about this refreshing game, amongst the norm of call of duty and battle field games, that this is original to a degree, and not some tired franchise which is loosing ideas!.

I spoke to one of the Devs to ask if there was any plans for future expansions, and sequals!.And they emailed me back and said they would love to if the game does well and the interest was there.

Even at full price this game is cheap, and I would happily have paid double for such a awsome,charming,fun and funny game with well balanced controls and difficultly to.

Two more things to mention is it has alot of graphic options for low and very high end PCs, which you can tweak to your needs and full game pad support to.
Last but not least it has a great Caribbean music which fits the game perfect, and makes you feel you are playing a Nintendo game from the 90s even more!.

So all that's left to say is buy buy buy!
And after if you don't like it within the 2 hour play time, then get a refund! But I will be surprised if you do!.üòä

author: {'steamid': '76561198056464732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 565, 'last_played': 1473426065}
review:
The game's first 30 minutes or so, it already feels incredible. It looks great and runs smooth when you have fps cap set to uncapped. The soundtrack just makes me happy and gives a big nostalgic boost to n64-era games. The platforming is original, it's something new and it works really well after an hour of messing around. Controller is needed for this. And you unlock customizables for your character!

For the price even a few hours of gameplay would've been worth it. But the game is bigger than the price indicates. The game is casual and makes me feel mellow. It's not hard at all, but with the weird and fun box-rolling physics I think that's a good thing.

The gameplay stays the same from the first to the third island. So no upgrades or anything, just custom looks for your box which isn't enough to make me want to collect everything in the game.

The multiplayer is actually really fun if you have 4 people to play with. Chaotic fun. 2 or 3 isn't enough because of the complex juming and rolling around the most experienced platformgamer will almost always win. So it's not a great party game. 

It took me about 10 hours to complete (without doing everything) and that includes playing multiplayer.

The game isn't comparable to super mario 64 or banjo-kazooie in my opinion, but then those were aaa-titles with the pricetag to match. What Unbox does do is give me that feeling of staying home sick when i was young while just watching cartoons. Relaxing, colourfull, smooth and fast (if your pc can handle it).

author: {'steamid': '76561198050452122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1521877433}
review: I have been looking forward to this since I saw it on the Unreal Dev blog, and it has not dissappointed. It's almost everything I hoped for. Assuming a big enough community could support it, I could see very good online multiplayer for this game as well!

author: {'steamid': '76561197967950811', 'num_games_owned': 2746, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 410, 'last_played': 1474930846}
review:
WOW, this game really took me by surprise.  No, seriously, I had never heard of this before it released on Steam, but I decided to take a gamble and buy it, and I'm blown away.

If you miss the 3D platformer/collectathon genre, and maybe you've been disappointed by some other indie attempts to mimic that genre, I think maybe you should try Unbox.  It does have similar gameplay to those N64-era favorites, but it's kinda doing its own thing at the same time.  Unbox isn't a straight-up clone of Mario 64 or Banjo Kazooie.. it sets out to provide a similar type of game, while bringing its own unique flavor.

The controls are solid (at least on a controller, I haven't really tried Mouse/keyboard yet), the gameplay and world seem polished, and the game gives you some really big, detailed worlds to explore, collect things, and complete challenges in.  It even has boss fights!

At the time of writing this review, I've played about 2 hours, and I've only just reached the second world (not counting the rather large hub area), and I'm having a great time. I've been collecting any collectibles that I've come across, and I plan on going back for the rest later, because I'm actually having enough fun to maybe 100% this.

If I had one thing to complain about, it'd be the music.  It's not bad or anything, you just hear it looping over and over and over and over again, and it gets kinda old after a while.. or at least the first world's music does.

Anyway, this is exactly the kind of thing I was looking for, and I was glad to stumble upon it.  It gets my full recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041513133', 'num_games_owned': 390, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1511333807}
review:
Game is cute and fun. The controls are easy to learn but hard to master. You will overjump at times but it helps make things interesting. Well optimized considering I'm on an old core 2 quad with 8gb of ram and a 750 ti. Heard of problems with a i7 and 12gb of ram and a gtx 730 then again a gtx 730 isn't really a good card. 

Also a little biased because I love 3d platformers and open world games. My favorite game of all time being both (jak and daxter seris on ps2).

author: {'steamid': '76561197996527857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1473046016}
review:
A cute and colorful platformer with a lot to offer! If you enjoyed the old rare platformer collect-a-thon style games of the N64 era, you'll probably find yourself loving Unbox!

The split screen multiplayer is a blast if you can get some friends together with a bunch of different modes and levels to choose from. Race and Oddball were my 2 favorites.  Chaotic fun!

I've only delved a little bit into the single player, but it's very charming so far. The gameplay feels tight, surprisingly since you're controlling a cardboard box. There's a ton to collect and explore! 

I'm excited to press on and see all that Unbox has to offer!

author: {'steamid': '76561198151801440', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 979, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 979, 'last_played': 1473806494}
review:
-:Updated 13th September to reflect 100%ing it:-

From the moment you start this game you can tell where it gets its inspiration and thats the games of Rare in the 90s. From the cute nonsense babbling characters to the light sense of humour, this is a love letter (no pun intended) to the likes of Banjo and so far I love it. The first world is brimming with charm; from the boxes that follow you around and welcome you to the little cars you can drive. I always think that you can tell the quality of a 3D platformer by how much you want to just forget about the point of it and explore, and this one had me doing it from the start (which is frustrating that it starts with a locked in tutorial).


Amount of content -

1x Hub World
3x Quest Worlds

Each world will take you around 2hrs minimum. I think most people will play it for between 8-10hrs and it took me 16hrs to 100% it. There is enough content to warrent the asking price, especially when you consider that the quest worlds are considerably bigger than a level in a game like Banjo.

Gameplay -

On the surface this is a collectathon like Mario64, Banjo etc, but it is not just copying them and I love the fact that it is also trying to bring something new to the table, which comes in the form of the unbox mechanic. This allows you to jump up to 6 times without landing, enabling crazy big jumps. The game suggests your health is connected to the unbox mechanic, however there are very few things that actually make you lose health which for me does diminish the excitement of it by the end.

Another way in which it builds on the platformers it takes inspiration from is the amount of character interactions. Not only are their quests to find, but people to talk to about the world you are exploring adding further flavour to the world you are tumbling through. 

The difficulty of the game is similar to the likes of Banjo with a mixture of stupidly easy to more fiddly tasks. However the tone of the game gives you the feeling of relaxed fun even when trying to judge the gap between two distant boats you want to jump to. 

Finally there is the customisation of your plain brown box. Completing the tasks and parts of the story lead to customisation unlocks which means you can turn your boring packaging into a weird bounding wonder. So if definining the protagonist your way is important to you then it is there and it is easy to do (you just need to find the tailor, which took me about 10mins after the first island unlocks).

Graphics and Technical Stuff.

The graphics are a mixed bunch with a combination of some great water textures and rock textures combined with some very plain ones mixed in, which works for the most part but at times can seem a little strange (watch the video above and you will see what i mean). However I found its short comings did not hinder the gameplay, which based on the first world I love.

It has an uncapped framerate and on my 970 rig will all settings maxed I was getting around 100fps at 1080p and there were no noticable major dips or stuttering. You can adjust things like FOV if you want and I know this is an important issue for some.

I would like to note that the game did crash for me while I was messing with the settings, but I suspect this was my firewall, because when I logged back in I had to allow the game access to areas my firewall didn't auto allow. After this initial crash I had no other bugs or crashes playing the game, however there was a little screen tearing which was largely removed by uncapping the framerate (others have suggested turning on vsync in your GPU control panel).

Controls -

How the character controls is important in a platformer as much as any other and I found the controls to be good; although controlling an object with sharp corners meant I needed a few moments to get to grips with how the box handles (because it does handle like a box and not like a ball). The vehicle controls do feel a bit looser and I am not sure how much that is me or the game.

The developers recommend a controller and because it is a 3D platformer I would agree, however I found it perfectly playable with WASAD and a mouse (mouse controls the camera and unbox mechanic while keyboard is used to move jump and interact). I could not get my DS4 to work with it natively, if that is how you like to game. However it worked great with my Xbox Elite and its paddles.

One issue I forgot to mention when I reviewed this initially was the fact that the controls are not customisable. So if that is a major issue for you, then you will need to take that into consideration.

Multiplayer -

This is local only and while it looks fun from YouTube videos I never had a chance to play it.

For Parents -

There is nothing in this game that would not be suitable for children of any age. The fact that enemies do not damage you, (only push you flying into the air and into the water grrr) and the fact that all enemies are boxes make it very kid friendly. Humour and tone has some more mature ideas but there is nothing sexual or particularly violent underpinning this game.

Overall-

All in all, I think this is a great game and I love my time within it. It is the 3D platformer I have been waiting for and wet my appetite for Yooka next year.

Hope this review helps anyone trying to decide whether to buy it. My advice is watch the video above on the shop page, it really does give a very good idea of what you are buying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021723352', 'num_games_owned': 1578, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1473208320}
review: Kinda has same vibe to it as Lego Island, so hey, thats pretty gud.
